reviewText:
"Dracula Untold" cleverly reboots the familiar Dracula myth to give our cinematic vampire both a backstory as medieval warrior Vlad the Impaler and a sympathetic origin. Vlad, a former mercenary in the Turkish Army, is Prince of Transylvania and a loving husband and father. The annual Turkish demand for tribute brings with it a new requirement: 1,000 boys to man the Sultan's army. Vlad faces an impossible choice. A refusal to comply will bring on a war with the Turks he cannot win, but to give up his son is unthinkable. A desperate Vlad will be driven to a deal with the Devil...

The presentation is darkly atmospheric, and generally succeeds in making Vlad a sympathetic character. The costumes, scenery and special effects are exceptional. The fight scenes between Vlad and the Turkish Army are good, if repetitive. Unfortunately, we all know how this situation works out. The film does manage a decent ending with forebodings for the traditional modern Dracula stories. Recommended as good entertainment.

I was disappointed when I read some unflattering reviews about this much anticipated movie, but I decided to watch it anyway. Im so glad I trusted my gut instinct and didn't listen to the critics. Maybe I was just in the right mood to watch it, maybe my expectations were lowered, or maybe its just a good, solid movie  but I LOVED it!

It moved fast, never dragged, and I was riveted to the screen for every minute. It mostly had to do with Luke Evans. I wasn't familiar with him at all and when I watched the trailer I wasn't particularly taken with his looks, but he is mesmerizing on screen as Dracula. He has an intelligence about him, with lots going on behind those dark eyes. He perfectly conveyed suffering, tenderness and, yes, a monstrous dark side.

The plot wins points for creativity and remaking Dracula as a hero. The writers incorporated enough of real historical events (the Ottoman Empire, the Janissaries being composed of non-Turks, and Vlad the Impaler having been a royal hostage in his youth) to give this untold story some solid heft. There are some plot twists that made me scratch my head and the fact that all the Transylvanians had British accents, but I can forgive most anything in a movie if it entertains the heck out of me  and this one definitely did.

I cant not talk about the special effects  AMAZING! I was breathless with awe. This is the type of movie that demands to be seen on a big screen. This is what I want when I pay $11 at the box office.

Now about that intriguing ending  I smell a sequel. Pretty please!!!!

Great Movie, perfectly cast. It tells how the Dracula bloodline began, and shows his human side. While it's not a scary movie (12- and 13-year olds would probably be fine), I wouldn't advise letting the younger ones watch; some images may be too frightening for little kids. It's worth adding to your DVD/Blu-ray collection.

This was not the typical blood-sucking vampire movie.  It was a story of a Prince who fought for many years of wars, to finally return home to his wfe, son, and the people of his kingdom, where he hoped to live out the remainder of his years (or at least the next 10) in peace.  But, it was not to be....

Prince Vlad had been called Vlad the Impailer because his prior war methods included impailing the bodies of his victims to rot.  Now times had changed and his army had apparently disbanded, with the exceptions of a few faithful soldiers.  Believing he and his kingdom were now vulnerable, the Turks demanded more than he was willing to gift and "negotiations failed".  In a last-ditch effort to save his family and his people, Vlad sought out some rather unorthodox methods to give him the edge.

There was lots of action, fighting, blood, and violence.  Not for the children, in my opinion, although I saw one there.

In this version, Vlad was the Prince who became Dracula to save his people and his family.  Luke Evans does a great job as the Prince.

Nine Things About the Movie Dracula Untold (USA, 2014)

1. This is yet another version of Dracula, that gets yet another origin story. But it's pretty decent, if you know what you're getting.

2. This is not your regular blood-sucking movie. This Dracula takes the semi-historical Vlad the Impaler route. Vlad is a prince who grew up captured and fighting for his enemies, the Turks.

3. Now back at home and ruling Transylvania, Vlad is threatened once again by the Turks. In order to save his people, he finds an ancient master vampire living in a Transylvanian mountain.

4. Vlad accepts a deal from the vampire, and begins his descent into darkness.

5. Vlad/Dracula is not evil in this movie, though he is an antihero. He is a physically and mentally traumatized man that feels a sociopathic duty to protect his people.

6. If you look at it right, this version of Dracula can be seen as a metaphor for war veterans with PTSD, trying (and ultimately failing) to keep their inner demons at bay.

7. A few characters from the original story make appearances in this movie; Mina appears briefly, and Vlad's gypsy servant Shkelgim is clearly the Renfield character.

8. The movie's atmosphere and cinematography are great. There are a few scenes that are absolutely, gorgeously gothic.

9. The movie touches on some deeper issues, but never explores them. So in the end, there's nothing about this movie that makes it particularly memorable. You watch it, then you go on with your life. But as an entertaining dark fantasy adventure, this is worth a look.

Luke Evans gives us a different type of Dracula, one I didn't expect. The childhood of Vlad is read to us. Vlad becomes the reluctant monster in order to have the strength to save his people from the Turks who are demanding 1,000 boys in addition to the tribute. Vlad enters into "the immortal game of revenge" to turn him into Uma Thurman on steroids.

I enjoyed the set up and the initial battle. The film slowed after that until the ending fight scenes which were anti-climatic at that point.

And what was that with vampires and silver? Silver is for werewolves. That made the whole film unbelievable.

No F-bombs, sex, or nudity.

I was absorbed by this version. I think is one of the most pertinent versions where non-fictional history is presented and blended with legend and myths. You can find out (finally) some actual facts about the Romanian history (son and father) + the role of Turks in those times. Although the turk characters were not well selected (they don't look like Turks) the illustration of their power and methods is pretty accurate.

The storyline is clever, detail oriented, selling you the whole story in a very credible way.

From second one until the end, the movie kept my attention and implication. A popular story with a serious delivery. A well earned 5 stars, in my opinion.

There's only a droplet of historical truth in Dracula Untold, a film that dares to take the king bloodsucker and give him a full-blown superhero origin. That's right, Dracula, once the scourge of Universal's classic array of movie monsters, is now on the side of the angels...which is weird considering his lack of soul and all. This version is a fearsome warrior, a defender of the innocent, a caring father and husband who gave up literally everything to protect his people. It's the Marvel-ization of Dracula in a PG-13, multiplex-ready package, but in exploring the myth of Vlad the Impaler the film offers plenty to sink your fangs into.

So how in the world do you make a guy named Vlad the Impaler a good guy? It seems like the kind of task any writer would balk at, but you do it by coming up with an enemy that's far worse or giving him a just cause to fight for. Luke Evans, whose chiseled features have been seen recently in Fast & Furious 6 and The Hobbit, plays Vlad before he becomes the Dracula we're all familiar with. Voiceover gives us his origin before the origin, recounting his time as the brutal slayer nicknamed "The Impaler", for reasons that are pretty obvious. But he's given up fighting and has retired home to Transylvania with his lovely wife Mirena (Sarah Gadon) and young son Ingeras (Art Parkinson). However when Turkish ruler Mehmet II (Dominic Cooper, looking none too Turkish) demands 1000 boys to fill his army's rank, Vlad does what any self-respecting leader would do. He climbs a mountain where he encounters he knows a vicious creature (Game of Thrones' Charles Dance) lurks, and enters into a Faustian bargain he may soon regret.

While we all know how Vlad's story will eventually turn out, Dracula Untold keeps us intrigued by the sheer desperation of his scheme. Granted incredible vampiric powers for three days, Vlad must also refuse to give in to the blood thirst that plagues every vampire. If he can deny it, he'll return to normal; but if not he'll be damned for eternity. The creature, credited simply as Master Vampire, is a trickster of sorts, gambling his own freedom on Vlad giving in to the lust for human blood.

It's the constant struggle for Vlad's soul that drives much of the story, as his family begins to fear him and so too the people he's sworn to protect. Glimpses of his evil future arise in brief flares of anger directed at his own soldiers, but Vlad's wrath is mostly reserved for Mehmet's army. Impressively scaled battles, murky and violent CGI showcases ala 300, nonetheless are pretty bloodless which may disappoint those looking for something more gruesome. They're in the wrong place if looking for horror thrills as debuting director Gary Shore has mapped out this story as an action flick, first and foremost. The visual effects are incredibly well done, from Vlad's "radar vision" to his ability to use transformation as a deadly battlefield weapon. Ever seen an entire battalion wiped out by a swarm of bats? You will in Dracula Untold and it looks spectacular.

There's very little connection to the Dracula we're familiar with, and the film works best when you forget everything that came before. If you can't, it may be tough to swallow that Dracula is really just a nice guy who made a noble, if tragic mistake. Evans is probably the most handsome Dracula to ever hit the screen and there's real passion in his performance. Other than Charles Dance who strikes a fine balance between mischievous and menacing, the rest of the cast barely register.

Designed as the beginning of Universal's newly-minted "cinematic universe" of classic monsters, Dracula Untold makes for a curious yet successful franchise-starter. Mostly it deserves credit for putting the teeth back into Dracula's well-worn story.

Drawing in equal measure from both Batman Begins and Game of Thrones, Dracula Untold functions as a 15th-century superhero origin story for the iconic title vampire.  This may not be a variation on the Dracula brand many people desired, but the film plays well as a piece of Gothic action/adventure escapism.  The story begins with Vlad III (the Impaler) retired from combat, quietly raising his family and reigning over a peaceful kingdom.  After a rival despot demands a thousand child soldiers, Vlad turns in desperation to a vampire known to hide on a nearby mountain, hoping to use the substantial power of the undead to defend his people.  A new vampire-mythology twist (or contrivance) is introduced to augment and simplify the drama:  if Vlad does not dine on human blood for three days, his transformation will not be permanent, but he will be forever damned if he sips from a vein.  So he fights to resist temptation and maintain his tenuous grip on humanity when he is not decimating invading armies in either human or bat form.

In general, Dracula Untold strongly emphasizes atmosphere and bluster over character development and thematic depth, but this is not a major problem when it comes to a cut-to-the-bone hour-and-a-half popcorn jaunt, particularly one with a well-timed October release.  It is rather a feast for the eyes, from the sweeping, overcast wide shots of picturesque rural Northern Ireland (standing in for period Transylvania) to the Hammer-horror art-direction flourishes, from crushed skulls to a tarantula to a host of ornate armor.  Though definitely neutered for a more accessible PG-13 rating, the action sequences are exciting and possess a scope indicative of a healthy budget, and the performances are more than fine for the genre, with the chiseled Luke Evans glowering capably in the lead role and the drop-dead gorgeous Sarah Gadon exuding wistful old-world elegance as his princess.

Good vampire movie, but not nearly as good as Underworld Series.  Costumes were excellent, Special Effects excellent, Acting very good and Story Line was very good.  Like Underworld, movie was mostly cloud covered or night scenes ... so you'll not see a lot of vivid colors.

As a true admirer of the real Prince Vladislav III Dracula I was very hesitant about watching this movie since it had nothing to do with the real man and was really about the fictional character created by Bram Stoker.  True some historical facts were thrown in even if they were inaccurate for the most part.  I finally watched the movie and was greatly and pleasantly surprised by how much I liked it.  It does a descent job in fleshing out some of the backstory on Bram Stokers Count Dracula, but has him surviving into the current time whereas in the book he is destroyed by Johnathan Harker and Van Helsing.  It is a good and entertains flick.
LOVE IT!!!
NOT BAD

RELEASED IN 2014 and directed by Gary Shore, "Dracula Untold tells the origin of Dracula: In the 15th century Prince Vlad the Impaler (Luke Evans) must protect his small kingdom of Wallachia (in modern-day Romania) from a Turk warlord (Dominic Cooper) who demands a thousand boys from Wallachia & Transylvania, including Vlads son. Threatened by the unsurmountable Turk army, Vlad desperately makes a dubious pact with a formidable caged vampire in order to acquire its dark powers and save his family & kingdom. Sarah Gadon plays Vlads winsome wife.

The producers flirted with the idea of Dracula Untold being part of Universals Dark Universe; and the epilogue of the movie, set in the modern world, suggests this, insinuating a franchise. This idea was dropped, however, and The Mummy (2017) became the first official film in the Dark Universe. In any case, Dracula Untold was fairly successful at the Box Office, making $56.3 million in North America and $217.1 million worldwide against a cost of $70 million.

My title blurb pretty much tells you all you need to know: Dracula Untold is basically the dark Superman of 15th century Eastern Europe where Dracula wields the power to defeat a thousand-man army. If you like the great prologue to Coppolas Bram Stokers Dracula (1992), youll probably like this movie, which gives several nods to that forerunner.

The film LOOKS awesome and has a fine cast. But unlike Bram Stokers Dracula, its rapidly paced and doesnt leave much room to breathe; so the characterizations aren't quite deep enough. Its good, but somehow hollow and forgettable. Bram Stokers Dracula was perhaps a little too slow while Dracula Untold is too hurried. I wish the creators found the happy medium between the two because, with just a little bit more time and attention to detail, it couldve been great.

THE MOVIE RUNS 1 hour, 32 minutes and was shot entirely in Northern Ireland. WRITERS: Matt Sazama and Burk Sharpless.

GRADE: B

I love this movie, maybe just because I love Luke Evans so much, but I liked the story.  It humanizes the man before the vampire.  Special effects were really cool.  And Luke Evans.......... so handsome!!!

The movie is visually beautiful, but lacks a sustainable plot. Read The Historian for a better vampire story of Vlad the Impaler.

Honestly I thought this movie was really cool. The effects were on point, and I enjoyed the storyline. The main actor was really compelling, and there were actually several moving scenes involving his family (and of course his transformation into a vampire). Haha I know, it sounds dumb to praise a vampire movie for its weighty emotional scenes, but I do think that the genre is a good place to explore ideas about death, sudden life changes, being estranged from loved ones, and of course immortality.

Granted, some of the dialogue is quite clunky. But overall the movie is a fun ride and it's not nearly as bad as the critics make it out to be.

I was ready to treat this movie like a silly knock off of the huge dracula movie encyclopedia but it was great.  It was like shakespeare dracula.  Honestly good acting from really experienced talented folks like Charles Dance(Tywin Lannister), Luke Evans(Gaston in Beauty and The Beast), and Sarah Gadot of Alias Grace fame.  It's such a timebomb story line where Vlad has only a few days to figure out his moral dilemma.  Honestly, it really feels like a shakespearean tragedy.  The Tragedy of Vlad Dracula.  So good.  Give it a shot.
enjoyed the movie

This was an interesting twist on the Dracula blood train. I happen to like Luke Evans and adore Charles Dance, who always plays a baddie to perfection. What made this movie different was creating a compelling Vlad, who was driven by love of family & his people, rather than the blood-thirsty Vlad killing machine who enjoyed torturing people, which is how most films portray this character. Also, there's some notable subtexts regarding the Turks. All said, I found Dracula Untold to be an enjoyable film.

Luke Evans holds it all together. Finally got around to Dracula Untold. Approached it without much enthusiasm, low expectations. 2nd tier Orlando Bloom did about as good a job as youd expect from the guy who looks like the guy who plays Legolas  he was OK. Charles Dance classes up any movie, so theres a high point.
The history is all wrong, wrong, wrong. Thats an annoyance. I thought the whole enterprise was weird, though. First, we want to have a vampire who isn't really evil. Story-telling wise, the moral conflicts added some much needed tension to the otherwise not-that-interesting story arc.
Heres the problem: our expectations have gotten really high. We aren't impressed with turning into smoke or moving kinda fast. Were not impressed with pretty fangs and frock coats. The movie turned Dracula into a superhero.
He can fly. He morphs into a cloud of bats that can fly faster than bats, and can also do other handy things  like turn into Gods Fist. In his first scene as a vampire confronting an army, he wipes out the whole army, by himself, in a few seconds.
Go back and watch the old Conan movies. Arnie was so huge, the directors had a hard time presenting him with and serious challenges. They had to resort to football players and basketball players to find people who existed on his scale. At the end of Destroyer, he fights a costumed Andre the Giant.
The Superman franchise jumped the shark a long time ago. In the 40s, he beat up mob bosses and jumped over cars. Now he throws continents into space and bullet bounce off his eyeballs.
Whatever.
No realistic threats. No limitations. Snooze.
The thing is, really the only threat to Dracula, once he meets the ex-machina Charles Dance Master Vampire in a cave, is the moral question: hell have to do some unpleasant things to protect his people. That could have been played much stronger. But it wasnt. In the end, his Turkish enemy inexplicably manages to sneak into the castle while Dracula is distracted fighting the army. Equally inexplicably, his mortal enemy seems to know what vampires are and that they don't like silver. These things are corrections to the godlike power given the title character which itself covers up for poor story telling with spectacle.
There is some spectacle. Almost-Orlando-Bloom is almost as pretty at Orlando Bloom; he looks pretty good in his armor. The special effects are OK, if you're into that kind of thing. But I just couldn't maintain serious interest in this film.

Apparently, Dracula was just a misunderstood prince among men.  He wasn't really bad, he had to be to save his people.  When an Ottoman scouting party is killed and drained in a cave near Vlads home, Vlad realizes hell get the blame, and sure enough, he does.  Sultan Mehmed II demands tribute and 1,000 boysplus Vlads son.  Whats a prince to do?  He makes a deal with a vampire and the rest is historyor hysteria.  Vlad literally goes batty.

Well, the scenery is lovely.  And Charles Dance as Master Vampire is incredible.  As for the retelling of a famous tale.  Some things should be left well enough alone.  This was very definitely meant to be part of a series repurposing the old horror icons.  So far, none of the entries in this proposed series has met with approval enough to incorporate any of them into a library of villains.  Universal Pictures Dark Universe recently pinned all their hopes on The Mummy remake instead.

As for this monster movie, its brief at a mere 93 minutes.  Its not particularly gory or scary.  Everything is artful and tastefully done.  I found it peculiar but fun.  They intend to remake it again at a later date.
Excellent movie
EXCELLENT MOVIE!

Very new and interesting take on a well known story.  Acting was good, storyline moved right along.

I would say it is a perfect balance between fantasy and reality mixed together in a blend that creates a more formidable Dracula. The action in the movie is pretty good for a PG13 film and the CGI was done very well. Give it a buy if you like a plot with awesome action.

I first saw this movie with my sister Ruth; who has sinced past away; but Ruth could really relate to Dracula's wife wanting to be (Mother/Wife/Nuturer, Protector, Provider, Warrior Princess/Queen) to her family. Vlad Tepes is often seen as a hero in his Native Romania; yet the rest of the world outside of Romania does not see it that way; because most people would not do anything or whatever they have to do to protect their partner, family, children, and country; this takes a certain kind of inner strength and staying power that has long past the millenial generation. If you set aside the Science Fiction element of the movie and look strictly at a man willing to do anything to protect his family, country from the tyranny of the Ottoman Turkish Muslim Empire; then there lies the beauty and strength of Dracula/Vlad Tepes. They don't make men like that who would stop at nothing to protect his wife, child, and country. Every man should be Dracula to his family/country:  (Protector, Provider, Warrior). Luke Evans a man who also loves his family, LGBTQPAI Community,  and country very much catches the very essence of Dracula. Luke did an amazing job and so did the entire crew. I watch this movie every night; and I say this is what I want to be to my family and country (Mother/Nuturer, Protector, Provider, Warrior Princess). This inner strength, spirituality, love, honor, and staying power I have found in the real vampire community/energy workers community more so than any organize religion or faith. Dracula Untold is one of my favorite movies; I can relate to the pain of Dracula losing his wife; because I lost my sister Ruth Guzman on October 19, 2015. Ruth & I shared a love of this movie & watched Dracula Untold all the time; when we visited each other. Sometimes we would just turn Dracula Untold on and have it on in the background; so when I do watch Dracula Untold now; I like to think; my sister Ruth is in heaven watching it with me.

The similarity between this film and other tales about the mythical figure Dracula is close to non-existent; yet the tale told in this film is exciting, dramatic, and full of suspense, with a surprise ending.
In this version, the year is 1462. The Turks want to capture and hold the entire world. To augment their army, they insist that various kingdoms give them young boys that they can train to serve in their forces. They did so with the now king of Transylvania. He served the Sultan when his father, the then king, was forced to give him to the Sultan's army. Now, the Turks have demanded 1,001 young boys; the one being the king's son. The king's wife persuades him to refuse.
The king has no army to speak of and agrees with an unidentified man, later seen as a vampire, to become a vampire with all the powers of a vampire so that he can fight the Sultan's forces. He is told that if he drinks blood during the upcoming three days, he will remain a vampire forever. He is also told that if he does not drink blood during the three days, he will return to a normal human.
The question is: Can he defeat thousands of soldiers by himself in three days?

This is a work of art. The special features about how some of the scenes were filmed were an education. Nowadays you almost expect to hear someone say, somewhat disparagingly, "Oh, yeah, that was done with Photoshop." It takes a true artist's eye to put together images as intense as are seen, especially the battle scenes. Magnificent!

Caution: Spoiler: In the commentary, the gripe was made that the closing scene in the marketplace had to be filmed when it was mostly bright daylight. In Stoker's novel, Vlad is able to walk about in the sunlight; after all, Vlad is some 400-600 years old, and should have some immunity to sunlight. So, I see nothing to gripe about in having had to film in daylight. That goes right along with Stoker's plot all along. Why not?

Vlad the Impaler as a family man is just a hard concept for me to swallow. I understand that you have to try to make Vlad a more likable character if he's going to be the star of your film, but they just make him so wholesome and sickeningly sweet, that it's hard to imagine him becoming the Prince of Darkness. (Which, spoiler warning, he really doesn't, because this film carries on the trend of making Dracula a romantic hero. Spare me.)

Personal preferences aside--I dream of the day where we once again have a Dracula that we can fear and loathe--the movie is just rushed. Aside from Vlad, Ingeras, Mirena, and Mehmed, I really couldn't tell you any of the other characters names. I assume that some characters are supposed to be important--the monk, the crotchety old man who is always seemingly trying to get rid of Ingeras, Vlad's many disposable friends, that creepy guy who follows Vlad around--but they're never given any character development. There's barely any time spent with any of the characters to make me really care what's happening to them or even really remember who they are. I've read some reviews that say that the movie moves as a fast pace, which it does, but it moves at such a pace that nothing really happens. It moves from one scene to the next without really setting anything up.

The ending makes it seem like they're setting up for the Avengers of Universal monsters, and God help us all of it actually happens.

Again, not a bad movie... But if the investers would have ponied up the dough for a better composer, it could have been an epic film. Dont get me wrong, the composers score was functional and got the point across, but nothing more. The score was forgettable and generic.

This movie is a grand example of how one should not trust the reviews and half-assed critiques one will find regarding movies that are all too often  pushed aside for common sensationalist pap.  Take a chance, and trust in your own instincts regarding films, and you will find that many will suit you just fine, and may in fact, prove to be far better than you ever would have thought.  This, my friends, is one of the good ones.

For the fans of the classic legends of vampires, this movie shows that it is possible to bring a new spin to a venerable creature of the night.  Even the fans of the "fluffier" style of vampire might enjoy the romantic side of the titular character.  But, unlike modern vamps, who are written to avoid the difficulties of daylight, or blood, or silver, Vlad Tepes/Dracul brings us back to those roots and demonstrates how an old school vampire manages 'like a "sir"'.

"Vlad Tepes (Luke Evans) is the Prince of Wallachia /Transylvania. Vlad and his men find a helmet that means an Ottoman scouting party is clearing the way for an invasion force. At Broken Tooth Mountain, Tepes finds a cave littered in bone fragments. Inside the dark depths they are savaged by a fiendishly strong man-like creature, whose speed, sharp teeth and keen red eyes, spell the death of all of Tepes' men, but not without cost.  The wounded creature attempts to make Tepes his victim, but halts when sunlight causes his blood to burn and turn to ash on the wind.  Vlad returns to his keep, and a monk informs him that a vampire, once a man who bargained with the devil for power, is accursed, and must remain in his rocky prison until he can pass his curse to another through a pact sealed with the vampire's own blood.

Time passes, and Tepes is with his wife and son when a Turkish entourage arrive and see audience.  Tepes offers them the customary tributes of silver coins, but the Sultan, named Mehmed, states that a contingent of Turkish men are missing, with the clear indication that Tepes was behind their disappearance.  He then demands an additional tribute of 1,000 boys to be trained as soldiers.  Tepes refuses the demand, but he knows his army is insufficient to repel the Turks if they should attack, so he asks Mehmed, who has known him since childhood, to show leniency and leave the children be.  Mehmed is not swayed by his request and Tepes then offers himself in their stead. The Sultan then demands that Tepes' own son must come also. The boy tells his father that he is ready to join the Sultan's army, but Tepes kills the Sultan's men knowing that his actions will lead to war.

Driven to desperation, Tepes revisits the cave seeking help from the vampire who tells him of the steep price of such a bargain.  He holds forth a skull bowl containing a large amount of blackish vampire blood, and informs him that if he is able to resist human blood for three days, the deal will be nullified and he will retain his humanity.  But, should he fail, he will inherit the blood curse of vampirism for all eternity and he will be required to render aid to the vampire when he finds his maker and seeks revenge upon him.  Knowing that he has no choice if he is to save his people and his family, Tepes agrees and drinks the creature's blood completely.  Immediately, he is wracked with pain, and through gritted teeth he asks:

"What happens now?"

The vampire turns away as he says:

"Now, you die."

Drawing from history surrounding the actual Prince of Wallachia, the movie incorporates a heroic view of the main character, just as residents of that area hold now.  In this way, the story is a clever blend of romanticism, heroic sacrifice, infamous legend and historic events that is altogether entertaining and enjoyable.  It's dark, and moody and the characters are well played.  For those with teens and preteens, it's not all that bloody or gore-ridden, depending more on facial reactions and dizzying action to depict violence.  There is one sexual situation that is quite tame, and the movie doesn't rely on foul language or crudity to carry the story.  From beginning to end, it was a good vampire romp with great actors, great costumes, and dizzying quantities of bats.  How cool is that!?

If you are weary of vampires with the Star Trek: Next Gen. sinus-problem makeup to make them look "scary", or vampires that have had all the gritty, bitey fun stripped away, including the fangs, then join me in some classical throat-sucking warfare that you'll really enjoy.  The end of the film implies a sequel, which I do hope eventually gets made, and I for one, want more!  A lot more!  I've honestly had all the wimpy sparkly vamps I can handle for one lifetime.

I'm into vampire films, so perhaps I'm biased, but I thought this one was decent. It suffers from melodrama (but that goes hand-in-hand with many vampire films), things in the story that should have been fleshed out a bit better, random accents, and historical inaccuracies, but if you can handle that, it's worth a watch. The acting, effects, and scenery help make up for it.

The look of this flick is so digitally manufactured that it kills the aesthetic of what medieval Romania should look and feel like. I get the idea behind making movies loosely based on fact for entertainment purposes but when you add the strapping, handsome Vlad and his loyal cluster of well groomed "Bachelorette" contestants, well... you get the point.  I would add that Vlad never really spent much time in what is actually called "Castle Bran". The legend has been depicted in film and tv for 94 years now and "Dracula Untold" couldve stayed untold for another 94 yrs and moviegoers would be better off because of it.

The film examines the legend of Dracula, Vlad the Impaler, in his role as the savior of the trans-alps and the stopper of the Armies of Suleiman the Magnificent.

In the real world, when the sultan saw 10,000 men on spikes, he turned back to the Arabian lands.

In this version, Vlad resorts to consorting with evil entities to accomplish the same end.

The acting is very good.  It is an A-List cast.  The scenes are done very well thematically, and the props and CGI are superb.

It is a well done movie.

I loved Evans in The Hobbit series and I wanted to love this movie so much but it just did not seal the deal with me.

The plot was a nice take on the Dracula legend and Evans came across fairly well as a Prince who had to do horrifying things to protect his people but if you did not know the story of "The Impaler" and the history of the times it could have gotten pretty confusing.  I absolutely detest political correctness and they went all the way changing Islam into "The Turks" as the enemy which was mostly true but when they talked about marching to Vienna (Battle of Vienna, 1683 - a great story in itself) again, unless you knew the history before hand, it made no sense.  How many people know the geographical and political relationship between Transylvania and its surrounding areas, the city of Vienna (Austria) and the Ottoman Empire, i.e. "The Turks" referenced in the movie?

The special effects added almost nothing to the movie and the ending made absolutely no sense other than that it repeated a deal that really made no sense earlier in the movie.

Oh well, I own it and maybe late some night I might watch it again but it will be likely quite a bit into the future.  This movie is not going to be like "Silence of the Lambs" which I have probably watched 20 times or the ridiculous number of times I have watched The Hobbit series and the Lord of the Ring series or the Director's cut of Bladerunner.

Rewrite the script a bit, get rid of some of the special effects and take a hard look at some of the back up casting and try it again.  This could have been a good movie.

If you have read any of my other reviews you know that I am extremely critical of Hollywood for not having the courage to use Islam anytime the plot requires a foreign enemy, even when it is entirely justified in doing so.

Tom Clancys  The Sum of all fears, for example.  Instead of using the novels Muslim terrorists as the bad guy, a gutless Hollywood  shifted the enemy to some fringe criminal Russian gang. Making absolutely no sense to why a drug smuggling, gun running, criminal enterprise with no political motivations would want to kill thousands of Americans to make a statement.

Or, the 2013 Olympus has Fallen, an otherwise earnest suspense ridden attempt if they hadnt laughably used North Koreans instead of a much more believable Muslim terror group as the culprit in this film. How is North Korea going to mount an attack like that without some overwhelming presence here in the United States? Answer, they wont, but Muslims have desire, the hatred and the possible underground community to attempt something like that. And, some of those Muslims live here  right alongside of us. They are our neighbors, they work in our industries, and send their children to our schools.

But, of course, Hollywood political correctness would never assume to criticize Islam in that way. Russians and North Koreans, but not the Muslims, the only group to have seriously threaten the west in the last 25-30 years.

I was pleasantly surprised to find that isn't the case with the manufactured vampire movie, Dracula Untold, an Irish production starring Luke Evens in the title role with Gary Shore directing. Released in 2014 it can be seen now on Netflix.

The movie builds the prequel to Bram Stokers 19th century Dracula character, using Islam as a bad guy. Historically there was some interaction, sometimes violently between the peoples of that part of Eastern Europe and the rising spread of the new Ottoman empire, So, it had some historical precedence. As far as I know so far the Muslims have remained silent on this movies premise.

Years ago the film 300 was severely criticized by the Iranians for using Persian history as a nemesis even though this was before the onslaught of Islam. Their arguments fell largely onto deaf ears because this is the history of that particular event. The mighty Persian army was held off by 300 Spartan soldiers at Thermopylae almost 2500 years ago changing the course of history by saving Western Civilization at that time.

The laughable reaction the Iranians got from the rest of the world could be the reason the Turks, the historical descendants of the Ottomans,  are remaining silent, a little surprising especially since they are ruled by a big mouth dictator who is turning his country into the Islamic version of the Third Reich.  And, maybe the protectors of Islam in the west, i.e., CAIR thought better of it since there is some historical context for this movie also, and they took such a PR bashing on 300.

The fact is that the director and writers of this film could have gone the way of productions like The Sum of all Fears, or Olympus has Fallen and used any bad guy for the antagonist, any made up warlord trying to expand his realm since the story is obscure anyway,  but they didnt, they used the rise of Ottoman Islam, an accurate accounting of the history of that time and place, using creative license to explain the beginnings of Stoker's Dracula.

The cowardice of Hollywood that hides behind political correctness could learn a thing or two from this production effort. Islam and Christianity have been opposed to each other since Mohammad invented his religion 1400 years ago. The clash between them flared up from time to time and we should be cognizant of that history. Dracula Untold pays that history well.

When the Sultan demands 1000 boys from Vlad the Impalers kingdom including Vlads own son for his Janissary companies, Vlad was powerless to stop him. The Ottomans at the time were on the rise and were sucking up Christian kingdoms moving every closer from Eastern to Western Europe.
Janissaries were foreign soldiers used by the Turks to fight in their front lines so fewer actual Turkish soldiers would fall in battle.  The mentality was not unlike the Jihadists today who use women and children to fall in front of them so they can use it, to save as many of their soldiers as possible, to say nothing of propaganda value. Accusing Israel, the United States and other western soldiers of killing without regard to the innocent has gone a long way in international public opinion. Earlier incarnations of this method to save the empires soldiers, the 15th century Ottomans at least put weapons and trained the soldiers to fight, even if they were kept as slaves.

Vlad meets with the Sultan, tries to convince him otherwise, but the Turkish ruler explains that he needs this for his Vienna campaign. Historians of the era will take notice that Vienna didn't happen for at least 200 years later than this timeline. Historical mistakes notwithstanding Vlad is left with no choice because his much weaker forces will be defeated.

It is here where he makes his pact with a monstrous cave dwelling blood sucking entity to become the vampire that folklore history has traced to him. Going through this transformation he goes out to the battlefield and defeats this forward advance of the Muslims single handedly. He then turns most of his guards and some of their women into vampires and they defeat the entire Sultans army. The Muslims never had a chance against this western advanced literary folklore, an irony I am sure is lost on the backward, unimaginative Islamic world.

It was good to see a Muslim enemy defeated so thoroughly on the battlefield even if it was a 15th century fabricated tale. We should not be intimidated by Islamic juvenile whining, being insulted by the slightest fairy tale. Draw cartoons, make movies, tell stories that show the despicable part of their history. If our artistic community does not reflect the world around us then it will eventually lose its influence in that very same world. Wake up Hollywood, take a cue from Dracula Untold.

Despite poor critical reception, I actually really enjoyed this movie... Luke Evans was great, Charles Dance is creepy, but the villain is pretty bad.

This is a refreshing twist for those who are tired of the same old Dracula story or Twilight-esque love story; however, there is still quite of bit of Hollywood cheese, bits of bad writing, and not-so-great acting from the supporting cast.

On the other hand, Luke Evans is absolutely fantastic in this movie, and shows a bit wider emotional range than he had in The Hobbit films. Had it not been for his performance, I would have given this a three.

A lot of you bloodsuckers out there will love this review but you probably won't like me very much. You see, I know werewolves exist, I have seen one. Then again I am part Native American and part German. Scary enough huh? But for mummies, vampires (except for bats), space aliens and other creatures I have not seen, it is hard to believe in them. I never read the original Dracula by Bram Stoker, it seems none of you vampires actually have either. I can tell you this much, in my wildest imagination, I can tell you that kissing a vampire would be like kissing an ashtray, cold because the dead are ashes and none of them shimmer, sorry Twilight, you are not a believable writer, but I am happy you made a fortune off your slosh love story. Luckily you had Taylor Lautner to save your movie. I must say that your two leads look like vampires out of makeup, so you saved a lot of money there, my hats off to you.

Knowing Hollywood like I do, I suspect that all Dracula movies miss the point Bram Stoker tried to make. Although some of them are good, most should have ended up on the cutting room floor. Needless to say I am not a vampire movie fan and I have seen way too many. Then along comes Dracula Untold. I thought Oh my gosh not another one! I watched the trailer. Dang that looks good.

If I had to do a review of a Dracula movie, I had to like this. . . but why? First the love of a father for his wife and son. I had to put myself in Vlads place and wonder what I would do. Second of all I am not a warrior, but in this case, I sure would try.  This alone had more grit than any other vampire movie I have seen. It made sense and was not about random actions. Third reason, is that the movie actually was written well. Dead is dead, and they did not miss the mark on that one. Add great directing, excellent photography, fantastic actors, a good story, and you have an almost perfect movie.

Many reviewers did not like this movie, because they too got away from the basics of the Dracula Story. I think most of them were women and fell into the Twilight hype. However if you want a basic idea of Dracula, then you will want to see this. Based on all other Vampire movies I have seen, I rate this 5 out of 5 stars! Oct 10 2014 Review by Remmy Meggs remmymeggs.com

One of the best movies in years. The vid is shot from behind the eyes of Vlad the Impaller. Great effects, very intensely violent. This is not like some, teen-horn-dog, immortality fixation movie. There is no "sparkely" Vampires is this tale. This is not a gushy romance "I have crossed oceans of time looking for you"...pant pant type movie either. No. This movie mostely sticks with the TRUTH. THE REAL Vladimir Tepes. The legendary atrocities that Vlad committed had a purpose: In order to protect his people and loved ones he had to become something else...something much more horrible. NO, In the beginning, Vlad had to win by instilling terror into the hearts of those who dare oppose him. But even the worst he could do was just not enough. There was only one way to beat the massive Turk army building up its army to attack and slaughter everyone...Vladimir makes an unholy deal with a demon. That's all. This movie is an attempt to tell a compelling origin of the most famous of all vampires, spinning a tale of woe and sorrow and the torment of a man who willingly became a monster to save his family and people yet loses everything.

And it fails.

Oh you can clearly see how Vlad Tepes is supposed to be a good man loved by his family and admired by the people he is ruled over, and can understand why when he is put in a seemingly impossible situation he turns to the power of monsters to help him through it. But for me the problem is that the plot feels half-baked. As if the script had a defined beginning and end, but wasn't quite sure how the middle should work.

He doesn't want his son to be a soldier in the Turks army so he kills the men sent to retrieve the boy, starting a way with the most powerful military force in the world. He doesn't have the manpower to fight the war so he goes to a trapped vampire he conveniently found several days before, who in exchange for his freedom offers to turn Vlad into a vampire and if he can keep from feeding on blood for three days he will turn back into a human. He spends most of those three days evacuating his people until he finally confronts the Turk army, driving them away but losing his family and people to plot convenience which trumps his vampire powers.

This could have been a good movie, but as it stands I don't think it is.

I normally don't do film reviews, but I wanted to for this one because, when I saw the previews a while back, it didn't appeal to me at all.  I've seen too many bad vampire movies.  I have to say with this one however, the casting was on point, the story felt unique and original, the scenery was just awesome, the special effects weren't overdone, and it leaves you hoping for a solid follow up film.  There probably won't be, but this one satisfies, I just finished it and will be ready to watch it again soon.  Not that it's similar too, but others movies I'd rank it with for personal taste and to see again are Star Trek: Into Darkness, Live, Die, Repeat, John Carter and 300 to name a few; if you like those, than you will most likely enjoy this.

There were little things I would change, some were addressed in the bonus features but didn't come out as emotional in the film like the rivalry between Vlad and the Sultan, a glimpse into their relationships as kids would have been great; there were many night scenes which sounded awesome, gave the film a punch, but were dark and a little hard to see all of the great stunts; I was hoping to see him in wolf form, would have been the best; and the wings on the cover look friggin' cool but don't appear in the film; the creature in the cave's story could have been expanded on too, with him fighting alongside him or tempting him more, but overall, I would still stick to the 5 stars. I gave 5 stars, because I can't give 10.  This movie incorporated a lot of history.  I immediately felt an emotional connection to the protagonist Vlad, so expertly portrayed by actor Luke Evans.  I cried more than once for Vlad and choices that were made.

There few literary characters, Shelley's Frankenstein, Borough's Tarzan, Fleming's James Bond, and maybe Rowling's Harry Potter, who have morphed through the generations into superstar brands as has Stoker's Dracula. And, each generation, it seems, adds its own twist to "the prince of darkness". As a pre teen in the 1970s, I saw all the Hammer Films' horror flicks (Lagosi-Lee-Langela gave us some of the most chilly-and thrilling-Draculas of all time!). Today's "Dracula Untold", as the latest installment of the Dracula brand, does not disappoint. This prequel presents the father of all vampires as a noble, almost fairytale, hero who sacrifices self for the good of his community (yes, it's revisionist socialism; Stoker never envisioned this for his evil antagonist), a sort of remake of Kipling's Gugna Din. That said, the screenplay is plausible, the acting is agreeable, and the special effects are remarkable. Although this movie may not be for date night (lots of blood and gore), it is certainly suggested (little profanity and no nudity) for the Dracula aficionado and student of vampires. The interesting ending suggests a potential sequel, now wouldn't that be unusual- another Dracula flick!

This is probably not a horror movie for horror movie lovers. Not enough mind-searing images of terror and depravity. But if you want to see a well-acted and quite touching movie about a man who loves his family and his country and gives his very soul to try to save them, you won't be disappointed. Luke Evans is fabulous in the lead role, and all the actors do a fine job around him. I wasn't expecting much when I saw this, but I was very touched and entertained. If you're on the fence about watching, give it a try. The PG-13 rating probably turns off the hard-core vampire-movie fan, but it's what made me give this a try. Well done all the way around.

Beginning in the 15th century with everyones favorite historical Impaler, Prince Vlad (a true-life Wallachian hero), screenwriters Matt Sazama and Burk Sharpless imagine, ala Maleficent, an origin of a bold and noble member of royalty who turns to evil to protect his realm from the Turkish empire which seeks to enslave his people.
Desperate for help on the eve of an invasion, Vlad makes an impossible climb to the top of a spooky mountain to face the legendary beast withina demonic creature who is clearly the master vampire. So why don't we get his origin story? Turns out Dracula is just another tragic dude in a long line of tragic dudes. We equate Dracula the character as being vampire Numero Uno, so right off the bat (pun intended), were left wanting the origin of vampires altogether, not just this one. The creature (played with usual sneering evil by a slumming Charles Dance, the only one in the film who looks like they're having any fun) gives the brave Vlad the option of drinking his blood to gain his powers, but if he gives in to feeding on anyones blood in 3 days time, he becomes cursed forever. Why 3 days? Why not a week? Why not 43  hours?

Historical names are borrowed to seemingly root the story in reality, but dates and locales are way off here(Vlad was a Wallachian, not Transylvanian, prince). So much for historical value. There is definitely entertainment value to be had viewing Dracula Untold, though it is not intentional. Battle scenes where Vlad turns into a horde of millions of bats (where did these bats come from?) and mows down an army of thousands offered plenty of chuckles. Vlads former brother and now enemy, Ottoman sultan Mehmed II (Dominic Cooper) somehow has all the scoop on the latest vampire extermination trends, so he keeps plenty of silver around and knows that a stake in the heart and exposure to the sun could kill him. Even freshly new to his powers, Dracula has harnessed the ability to turn others into rampaging bloodsuckers and is also given Thors nifty powers of control over the weather, which comes in handy to block out that pesky sun. A particularly hilarious moment is when his wife is falling from the high tower of a mission (monks cannot be bothered to construct guard rails); Vlad jumps after her, and we go down in slo-mo, with a mournful exotic voice wailing in the background to underscore the emotion.

As Vlad, Luke Evans (last seen as Bard in The Hobbit movies) is full of brooding fury; we get the motivation for turning to dark powers, but he doesnt have the support of any believable transition. Everyone else plays stock characters. The cinematography is dark and muddled, like you're viewing the movie through a dirty window pane.

In trying to reboot Universals classic monsters legacy with an origin of the master vampire himself, the filmmakers completely lost sight of the idea that he kind of has to be scary. Vampires are so ubiquitous these days (thanks Twilight) in teen romance movies, campy sexy HBO series (True Blood), and philosophical, angst-ridden studies (Jim Jarmuschs Only Lovers Left Alive), that an entire generation has grown up on vampires that are everything but scary. This is not a way to reboot a monster movie. It would actually have been most refreshing to see him back in the shadows, emerging with hypnotic brows.

CLICHES: Throw a dart at any frame. SURPRISES: they do throw in a mysterious Renfield like characterseems theres always someone eager to serve a dark lord. YOU ALSO LIKE: for a scarier vampire tale, check out Showtimes original series, Penny Dreadful, a wonderfully eerie mashup of Victorian gothic monsters including the search for Dracula (avail on amazon). Let the Right One In (or its AMerican remake, Let Me In) is the best vampire film made in the last 10 years.

This movie looked lackluster from the previews, but the positive reviews persuaded me into a rental. Where I thought I might be getting a dull, boring Hollywood movie like so many others, something to be watched and forgotten (Underworld sequels for example), I actually found myself engaged with the narrative of this film. It was quite a bit of fun, well acted, and well paced. I didn't find myself bored which I assumed I would.

Dracula is portrayed as a sympathetic hero, a man made into a monster to save his family and kingdom from the overwhelming forces of the Turkish invaders, and at the time I viewed this movie I thought this might be a bit too Hollywood, but having since read some books on Vlad the Impaler (he was a real monster no doubt) there is a revered awe about his legend held by the people of the region. He is remembered in legends as a tragic hero, and this film captures that well. In fact, the filmmakers did their homework and made some nods to historical accounts. Though let's be honest, this is not an historically accurate film, and the filmmakers don't really try to pretend it is. If the choice is between historical fact and heroic character building, well let me assure you they always choose the latter.

Visually the film is interesting, Dracula's character arc is easy to get invested with, and his family does not feel annoying like I feared they would. I'd say check it out if you were hesitant and you love Dracula mythos, you'll probably be pleasantly surprised. This is no incoherent mess of Hugh Jackman Van Helsing slinging machine gun powered silver arrows at vampire harpies, nor is it a snoozing bore-fest of King Arthur with Clive Owen which in all its "true story"-ness became so unlike the classic tale it was not worth the price of admission, and so creatively bankrupt it was not worth watching.

Though at some points you may wonder how becoming a vampire equals controlling such unequaled power. It had a tinge of video game quality towards the end. I was reminded of Lords of Shadow. Which I won't complain about.

The year is 1492 Transylvania - The small Kingdom ruled by 'Prince Vlad' (The Impaler)(Luke Evans) has enjoyed peace for the
past ten years.
When during a Celebration the Kings envoy turn up to claim the fealty due, they also demand 1000 boys to serve with his armies'
the selection would also include 'Prince Vlad' and 'Mirena's' (Sarah Gadon) young Son, however 'Vlad' is not prepared to meet the
demands of 'King Mehmed' (Dominic Cooper) knowing the warlord will wreak vengeance upon his small kingdom.
Earlier 'Vlad' had lost two of his men in a mysterious cave on the side of a mountain that harbours pure evil, it is to this cave the
Prince turns too, to save both his family and his people, the cost to himself, eternal damnation, he will become something very
different with unimaginable power and senses, which have been passed to him by 'The Master' (Charles Dance)
The passion for his family and his people remains, he returns to his castle which is under siege from overwhelming forces - odds he
will not fear.
'Vlad' seeks to take his family and people to a safe place knowing the War-Lord King will hunt them down, as the days pass his need
for blood becomes intense....
The story to be told well needed more than the approx 90 minute run-time, the story perhaps a little fanciful stretching the story and
legend in the telling of the beginnings of Dracula, however if watched with little expectation, as a spectacle putting aside legend it's
a decent special-effects viewing.
As an earlier reviewer pointed out the role taken by Charles Dance somewhat beneath his acting prowess in truth.
Good Picture and Sound Quality
Features -
* Alternate Opening
* Deleted Scenes
* Feature Commentary
* Day in the Life - Luke Evans
* Dracula Retold
* Staying 1000
* The land of Dracula
* Interactive Map
* Luke Evans - Creating a Legend

Luke Evans has presence, there is no denying it. He was dramatic, anguished, determined, and photogenic. He carried scenes all by himself. The weakest element of the tale was the romantic connection, it certainly didn't gel for me, though both Vlad and Mirena were lovely to watch. I think Mirena as played was too immature, not at all queenly. Another problem I had was there was no connection really to any of the other characters. No time taken to demonstrate the ties, it was like being dropped into the middle of a story without preparation. Brother Lucian, had a bit of chemistry with Vlad, if only the time had been taken to flesh it out. I wanted more, what had happened to bring them together as friends or persons with a shared interest? And Dumitru, he too could have been the brother in arms that gave the film depth beyond Vlad alone. In the few scenes they had together it was tantalizingly out of reach. Really I have to say, the film was rushed and a bit jumpy, yes. But time and again Evans (Vlad) caught my eye. Special effects, the flight of the bats, that was especially good.

Call me old-school, but I prefer my Dracula movies to avoid rewriting all the classic vampire rules. Bela Lugosi, Christopher Lee, even Barnabas Collins...they could all transform into ONE bat, not a swarm of (CGI) bats. Nor could they control a literal tsunami of (again, CGI) bats to battle the enemy hordes. And they most definitely can't be RE-transformed back into a human by passing along their vampirism to someone else. They should have called this turkey Lord of the Wings. After the first couple of massive fights between the CGI bat hordes and the evil Turks, I was yearning for a real Dracula movie. With the exception of a brief appearance by the Charles Dance, this flick is just another lame CGI-fest with virtually none of the elements of a memorable Dracula movie.

So I'm starting to sense a pattern in all my movie reviews...not sure why it took me so long, however i tend to write reviews based on rental viewing from the comfort of your own home. The movie experience, imo, changes the review completely if you have to drive to theater, battle parking, crowds, pay an insane amount of money for sustenance, fight for the 'perfect' viewing seat, only to be disappointed by a mediocre movie. Viewing from your home however, a mediocre movie suddenly isn't so bad. I have to say though, that if i did view this in the theater, i would not have been too disappointed, especially if it was a half price matinee. Pleasantly surprised on this one. While i was not blown away, this Dracula made for a pretty entertaining experience. First lets talk Luke Evans, where have you been hiding?? In  Hobbit garb, I'm sure, that's why I'm suddenly all sympathetic to Dracula. He did what he did out of love, what's a cup of blood or two?? That would be me. Great casting and cinematography. The only character that threw me was his little wanna be side kick. If anyone has watched Black Sails, Captain Vane makes an appearance as this mealy Gollum like character that just seemed all wrong. Looks wise, okay. When he spoke, it was just strange and weird and just seemed all wrong. The story was surely told from a different, albeit interesting angle which i think audience will like from the normal departure of Dracula, it kind of gives him a soul and i must say, i like this Dracula best. Near the end, I'm suddenly thinking that so many things about vampires make sense, as if trying to rationalize the phenomenon in modern day. That's a good movie, that makes fantasy perfectly normal. There was a bit of forethought with this story. The balance of the cast was not as strong but not terrible, but i honestly did not expect more. This was a strong B movie thinly disguised as an A ( think Hercules which, this was better, imo). The effects I'm sure would have been outstanding on the big screen, or just a giant TV. I'm fairly certain than anyone going into this with low expectations, i mean, it is Dracula, will be pleased with the outcome. It was the least cheesy, verging on non cheesy, of any Dracula movie or TV show in a very long time. I really do hope that there's a sequel, however making a modern day sequel may loose a bit of the drama and intrigue than keeping to the previous historical setting. I do recommend this for a night in with friends, it was dark with a good amount of action, drama, intrigue to make it a worthwhile Saturday night.

Gary Shore's "origin" story of Dracula isn't the first to film and certainly won't be the last.  Nothing wrong with that of course, so how does it play out here.  Frankly, the first part of the film is interesting and entertaining.  Prince Vlad (Luke Evans) of Transylvania was trained as a boy to be a soldier for the Turks who controlled much of the world in the mid-15th century.  He got quite a reputation as a relentless killer of his enemies, even staking them with long wooden poles.  Known as Vlad the Impaler, he is able to return to his throne.  Protected by the Turks, he has no army but rules the land peacefully with his wife, Mirena (Sarah Gadon) and son Ingeras (Art Parkinson) by his side.

When Vlad's childhood friend Mehmed (Dominic Cooper) becomes Sultan, he resurrects the old "drafting" of boys who will supplement the Turk's standing army.  Vlad of course objects to the demand of 1000 boys.  But with no army what is he to do.  Well, earlier in the story he and 2 of his lieutenants stumble upon a cave high in the mountains where they encounter a horrible demon credited as the "Master Vampire" (Charles Dance).  Vlad's life is spared.  He decides to go back and make a deal in order to gain the power needed to fight off Mehmed's troops.  The logic here is somewhat suspect.  I know Vlad is desperate but why would he think Master Vampire would accommodate him?  Well, wouldn't you know it, he does.

Vlad drinks a portion of Master Vamp's blood using a nearby cap of a human skull.  No neck biting here.  Master Vamp promises Vlad "the power of 100 men, the speed of a falling star" and perhaps the ability to leap tall buildings in a single bound.  In any case, if Vlad wants to return to his mortal self, he must abstain from drinking blood for 3 days.  And yes, stay out of sunlight and away from Kryptonite...I mean silver.  If he succumbs to the blood drinking, bam, he's a vampire forever and Master Vamp can leave his cave.

This mid-point in the movie is really where things fall apart.  Vlad's main method of transport is to transform into a bevy of bats and fly at supersonic speed.  So into the heart of battle he goes.  And manages to slaughter (without any blood on screen) 1000 of the Sultan's best soldiers.  Wait, no one said he had the power of 1000 men, it was 100.  With a storyline that suggests that this was the first of a series, Shore and his writers seemed to rush things, leaving huge plot holes, ridiculous actions and an overload of unnecessary CGI carnage.

Ultimately, the film which has some interesting actors and started out well, ends with a thud.  Rarely do I think a film has too short a running time, but this film ends with a bunch of poorly edited scenes.

The Blu ray transfer comes with a 1080p video resolution and a 2.40:1 aspect ratio.  Black levels are inky and certainly necessary in that much of the film is shown with dark night sequences.  Still color levels are good along with hues and saturation levels.  Excellent detail as well as noted in the elaborate body armor Vlad and Mehmed wear.  There is plenty of action in the film which serves the DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1 track.  Bats are flying everywhere and they surround the viewer if you have a surround set up.  An excellent musical score helps set the tone of the film.  The LFE channel gets a workout as well, especially in the battle scenes and the one where Vlad and his allies approach the final battle in an electrical storm.  At times, it seemed the surrounds overwhelmed the dialog but was easily adjusted.  Subtitles are available in Spanish, French and English SDH.  Here are the extras:

*Feature Commentary with Director Gary Shore and Production Designer Franois Audouy
*Day in the Life - Luke Evans
*Dracula Retold
*Slaying 1000
*Alternate Opening with Optional Commentary by Shore and Audouy
*Luke Evans: Creating a Legend
*Deleted Scenes with Optional Commentary by Shore and Audouy
*The Land of Dracula

I went into this movie with a great skepticism that I would like it at all.  It's a clear deviation from Bram Stoker's Dracula, and that both bugged and intrigued me before watching.  but I actually did enjoy it. Sure the history and facts are skewed all over the place, making it no better than Stoker's in that respect (or maybe worse?), but I thought it was actually nice to see a different backstory to Dracula, and overall it was a generally entertaining movie. I forgive the plot holes because, after all, it is a vampire movie, much like I forgave the many plot holes of dawn of the dead because it was a zombie movie. (please dawn of the dead fans and Dracula untold critics, don't start commenting about comparing the two--I'm not-- i'm only mentioning that both had plot holes that i overlooked for the enjoyment of the movie)

A Dracula origin story was never something that needed to be made...not by even the wildest stretch of the imagination. That said, Dracula Untold (ignoring what is arguably one of the single most insipid titles that could have been chosen) wasn't altogether a bad movie.
It isn't a masterpiece and it won't be the sort of movie that will be cherished decades from now as a great piece of movie history (unless the events of Idiocracy come to pass)...but it was a solid bit of filmmaking. Had different actors been cast in a couple of the roles it would have been the sort of movie worth little more than a laugh and some well-deserved derision. The special effects weren't bad either, though I have seen better.
I don't recommend rushing out to pick up a copy or anything, but if you get the chance, it is worth taking the time to sit through it and enjoy it for what it is...a monster movie made in the tradition of the old Universal monster movies, and as such it was a suitable homage.

Since Dracula the TV Series was cancelled after one season, I was looking forward to this movie.  It didn't disappoint, which is why I was so surprised at the mixed to negative reviews for it.  23% on Rotten Tomatoes.  40% on Metacritic.  6/10 on IMDB.  I thought it was certainly better than mediocre, and it actually follows real history more so than almost all "Dracula"-based movies and TV shows I've seen.  I'm a huge fan of history, so that's a plus in my book.

So, if you like Dracula-inspired media and are a fan of history, I believe you'll enjoy this as I did.  If you hate history or dislike movies that get into the finer details, you may want to skip it.

An excellent action/fantasy that combines history with legend. Vlad III, prince of Wallachia (Luke Evans), who eventually becomes "Dracula, son of the Devil", is based upon Vlad the Impaler, a 15th century leader of Romania capable of incredible cruelty, who would impale his victims.

As Vlad III rules in peace at the beginning of the movie, Sultan Mehmed II (Dominic Cooper) asks Vlad for a thousand of his boys, eventually including even his son Ingeras (Art Parkinson), to serve the Ottoman Empire, instead of just the usual tribute. Vlad goes to Broke Tooth Mountain to seek the strength of the Master Vampire (Charles Dance) in order to resist the Turks. As the suspicious Vampire has his hand on Vlad's throat, Vlad says, "Sometimes the world no longer needs a hero. Sometimes what it needs ... is a monster." This makes me think of something I once heard a priest say on a television show: "At a time when the world had stopped believing in the Devil, Hitler came into the world and showed it the face of the Devil." - Father George William Rutler

Back to the movie, where if Vlad drinks some of the Vampire's blood, he will gain the Vampire's strengths to take on the Turks. But if he subsequently drinks someone's blood before the third day, he will become a Vampire. If he doesn't, he will resurrect, so to speak, to his former self. Vlad drinks, making a pact, a deal with the son of the Devil, so to speak. With the Vampire's strength, Vlad has the ability to take on "a thousand" man army by himself. (Someone younger needs to be able to do that, Sly, Arnold, Bruce, and Liam are getting up there.) 3 and 1000 are important numbers in the Bible. Christ rose on the third day and His servants will reign with Him for a thousand years (Revelation 20:4; 7:4-8).

As the soldiers of the Ottoman Empire are coming for Vlad, a group of his subjects are on their knees in prayer to which Vlad responds: "The Turks are coming. Prayers will not defend these walls. Get these men off their knees." Why not have the women, children, and men who can't fight continue their prayers  while Vlad and his soldiers prepare to fight (and they should be praying too)? The Feast of Our Lady of the Rosary on the Catholic Church calendar commemorates how the Christians turned back the Muslims at Lepanto to save Europe while the Pope prayed the Rosary.

But Vlad subsequently makes his own prayer in a church: "Lord, if you've not yet forsaken me, grant me your strength that I may resist the darkness. Allow me to endure this test one more day. ... I beg you. ... Please."

This made me think of some Scriptures: "Then he told them a parable about the need for them to pray always without losing heart ... 'Watch and pray that you may not undergo the test. The spirit is willing but the flesh is weak. ... Sufficient for a day is its own evil. ... My grace is sufficient for you, for power is made perfect in weakness.'" - Luke 18:1; Matthew 26:41; 6:34; 2 Cor 12:9

The acting in "Dracula Untold" was excellent. Luke Evans definitely has a strong presence. The movie is definitely a strong PG-13, meaning the bloodletting, war scenes, and a bit of sensuality are inappropriate for pre-teens and the squeamish. I'll end with a quote I recently came across that seems to fit here:

"The difference between the City of God and the City of Man is like the difference between Jesus Christ and Dracula. Jesus Christ shed his blood so that you can have eternal life. Dracula sheds your blood so that he can have eternal life." - E. Michael Jones
("The Culture Wars come to India", Culture Wars magazine, March 2015, P.27)

The Dracula story told again.  Prince Vlad must defend his homeland from the invading Turks, but how can he and his small band stand against the hordes?  He must seek out new power.  This Dracula story is retold from the perspective of Dracula as the reluctant anti-hero whose hand is forced.  While certainly not Bram Stoker, this is a fun adventure story akin to Van Helsing, and Hansel and Gretel:  Witch Hunters.

I never thought I will write a review for a movie with Dracula.
But now justice has been done! It has action until the end. It has love until the end. It has passion and good soundtrack! It also has  a joke! It has a story and it shows you the story. That means you will maybe cry, cuddle, laugh and get scared.
It is not just a movie about Dracula, the one most people are used to. It is also a history lesson with great lines to remember. The filmmakers have done a great research, have put a lot of energy in understanding Vlads time and his personality. All in all, what I can say is that this movie matched both history books I have read about Vlads reign. Justice has been done, no matter how much Id like to see a movie about Vlad Tepes  something close to The Gladiator, that means without devil. The entire team has done a great job.
Vlad was a prince of innocents  and this has been shown across the entire script. Yes  it has DRACULA, but also the real history (the untold)  how great can that be: to keep a name alive for centuries as Dracula then revive it in all its greatness? How would world look like under the Ottoman Empire?
Vlad Tepes is a hero because all he wanted was peace and justice while all he had was a small army and God. Thats how he defended Christianity and Wallachia (nowadays ~half Romania).

I recommend you not to only see the movie, but to also buy it. I am not sure if Id like a sequel more than a prequel. Whatever it will be  it must be at least to this level of Dracula Untold.

Luke Evans IS the film. The story is easy to digest.  Most of its appeal comes from the acting talents of Evans, Charles Dance,
and Dominic Cooper. The rest is a whole lot of C.G.I. razzle-dazzle, which is to be expected these days. Sometimes, however, I believe when you have talent such as Luke Evans in a film, the directors/writers should do more to showcase the actor's ability to act rather than  so much focus on technology.  I'm frankly a little weary of all the special 'effects' I see in films today. I say, let the actors ACT. I watch movies for the acting first, then story, then everything else. Put the emphasis back on story and use technology sparingly.

That being said, I recommend this film for a fun night with your 'significant other'. So grab a bowl of popcorn and enjoy Luke Evans reveal his positively gorgeous body and fine acting!.

This movie starts with the premise that the legend of Dracula begins with an historical figure named Vlad the Impaler, and then says: Let's make this guy real; lets try to make him sympathetic; lets show some of the struggles between empires that were going on at the time, and then let's make it fiction with some historical realism by imagining he really could become...a vampire.  Overall not revolutionary but reasonably decent.
As "A World Undone" explains nicely, the Balkan region (which includes the former Wallachia) was and still is a very turbulent place for 3 or 4 reasons: 1.  Beginning with the split of the Roman Empire into Eastern and Western, each to have its own emperor.  This also led to the split of the Christian church into Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox, and the usual wars of religion.  2.  On top of that the Moslems entered the picture, in the form of the Ottoman empire which extended into Europe from the east at least as far as the Danube.  As a result the Balkans had the largest indigenous Moslem population of the European "continent", causing yet more divisions.  3.  Russia was constantly seeking control of access to the Atlantic via the Mediterranean, and key to that was control of the narrow waterways from the Black Sea into the Mediterranean.  The Balkans are just to the west of this fault-line.  4.  Through constant wars, migrations and boundary shifts, the whole area is a co-mingled mass of groups deeply suspicious of each other...

As an example of making Vlad the Impaler seem a reasonable guy, he explains it thus: "By impaling every living thing in one village, I saved 10 others, which quickly surrendered rather than endure the same horror."  See?  Actually a nice guy, once you get to know him...

I rather suspect his "bloodthirstiness" grew into legends of him actually drinking the blood of his enemies, and from there to him as some only partly-human, partly satanic being of legend.  Certainly the movie is not to be taken as historically accurate, but in a general way it does set the background for the legend.

Aside from the 1992 "Bram Stoker's Dracula" with Gary Oldman, this is the only other retelling of the Dracula mythology that I love.

This version, however, is based on the most original premise that defines and differentiates this version from all others.

It's beautifully directed and the acting is viscerally engaging. It's almost staged like a grand opera.

I would have preferred that the demise of all the vampires in the end would have brought down the curtain; however, I suppose it's only logical that his maker, who remained in hiding would revive him. How convenient for a possible sequel as we see Dracula and his maker strolling the streets in modern times. There are already far too many vampire stories saturating cable and the internet; hopefully the sequel (if there is one) will simply bring  the story to a satisfying conclusion as he has found his love reincarnated.

I love the story of Dracula and I found it interesting to show the beginning and how he changed. The Bram Stoker's book tells a little bit different story, but I liked that one as well. It was nicely done with good visual effects and a good story line. Having said that, something was missing, I am not certain what, but I had a feeling the movie was "empty of emotion". Yes, Luke Evans was great, but like the story was not exactly well told.

It is an interesting take on the Dracula legend, but the story is somewhat jumbled, rushed, and, in an effort to reinforce the story's "darkness", it's filming leaves a lot to be desired relative to simply viewing the movie.  The cast was good in their roles, but the direction and photography didn't live up to the cast and the storyline.

Not too far a departure from the folklore known, but far enough that it stands well on its own. Not exceptionally gory, and filled with romance, it is a true love story. But there are graphics of horror and new tech visions, some haunting some cutting, like painful incisions. The flower does delight, yet after a time does wilt. The joy of love follows the angels' lilt. And then in the shadows, as darkness falls, the blood-lusting demons siren their calls. Be careful where your foot does tread, beside the living, and near the dead!  BLOOD!

It really could have stood out as a decent work of fiction in my perspective if it didn't take so many liberties with fictionalized accounts, attempting to resemble history, to defame a race/religion/culture as an excuse for a story plot.

As someone marginally aware of world history and culture, who values the diversity of the world we live in, I feel what could have made a decent "supernatural" vampire story with a really great cast and special effects was instead lost in a sad excuse for a plot. Hence, for me a complete disappointment!
