In Dracula Untold, Vlad (Luke Evans) chooses to become the monster he fears to defend his kingdom from the Turks.

This Dracula movie is something a little different instead of the typical Dracula sci-fi movies that have graced the screen over the years. This one incorporates some historic elements (although not necessarily historically accurate) to explore the beginning of the fictional Dracula tale. I liked the different original approach to the movie and plot. Evans does well in the role of Vlad who is torn from saving his son and people to facing basically an eternal role as the Son of the devil as he puts it. In this tale, Vlad (Dracula) is not quite the hero and not quite a villain either and it works for the story. The special effects are also well done and reflect dark grim world in which this is set creating the right mood. Although this does have some plot holes and misses the mark in a few places, I did find it enjoyable enough to watch.

A different telling of the traditional tale that I thoroughly enjoyed. Great cast, wonderful action, beautiful settings. I've been a fan of the Dracula story since I was 8 years old, and I absolutely loved this version. It was refreshing. And what girl isn't swooning over Luke Evans right now? The fact that Charles Dance is in this had me clapping excitedly, as he is such an amazing actor. The story is amazing and still follows Vlad's life somewhat, but this one brings us his beginnings and shows us a little more into why he chose to become the vampire.
Interesting take on the back story and what lengths a man will go through when those he cares about are in danger.

I was very happy to see that this version expounded more on the history of how he became Dracula.  It explains that there was a man before the monster, who loved and raised a family, cared for those he was responsible for and who had to perform monstrous acts to protect those he loved.  Then, when no other choice was left he became a true monster to to effect safety for his people.  Modern technology plays a huge part in bringing to life the surreal aspect of an ancient tale making this latest re-telling well worth seeing.  From the original silent film "Nosferatu" through Gary Oldman's larger-than-life portrayal of Dracula and the Dracula 2000 film franchise we have been thoroughly entertained and Luke Evans has stepped-up and delivered.

I've got to say, I read the other reviews, and decided to just order it.  This was when Amazon had mis-published the page.  Initially it had said the running time was about 180 minutes.  I saw this and thought "Really?!  An origin story of Dracula that is three hours long?".  I was stoked because I love Bram Stoker's Dracula (1992) despite some of its flaws.  I had also thought "Well, I like the lead actor, too.  So, that helps".
I received the movie, it's 90 some minutes long.....HALF of what Amazon had initially advertised.  They must have counted the special features.  I had looked again, and they had changed it.
All this aside.  It is a good movie.  Rushed in places.  Charles Dance doesn't have nearly enough screen time.  It's times like that, when Vlad meets this mysterious vampire that could have been explored a bit more, as well as spending more time on Vlad's changing.  But having said all this, it's worth a viewing.  It's got some decent acting, fair story, and fantastic landscape.

Dracula as a character has had many incarnations over the years, from Bela Lugosi and Christopher Lee, to Frank Langella and Gary Oldman. All of these brought essentially the same story, but what distinguishes DRACULA UNTOLD is that it tells the heretofore "untold" origin story of one of literature's most enduring villains. Or is he really a villain? That's also something different that this retelling/reboot brings to the table: it recasts its titular character as a conflicted antihero, as is the fad right now. All of these elements could potentially make for a great film, but what Universal has delivered here is bland and uninspired at best. That's not to say this isn't a well-made film, but for all of the hoopla surrounding what is hoped to be the beginning of a Universal monster cinematic universe this film doesn't exactly inspire confidence in that regard.

 Even if you've never seen a Dracula film before, you probably already know about the character's origins as a Transylvanian prince. When the Turkish Sultan (Dominic Cooper) reinstates a tradition whereby 1000 Transylvanian boys (including Vlad's own son) are conscripted into his army, Vlad goes to a mysterious mountain in search of a way to protect his people. First, I'll get the positives out of the way. For the most part, the acting is solid. Luke Evans is decent as the titular Dracula, and he does a good job of selling him as a conflicted character. Dominic Cooper, although maybe miscast as Sultan Mahmed/Mahmoud, still acquits himself nicely by turning in a decent performance as well. I also liked some of the production design and sets. The visual effects were little more hit or miss, though. The first couple of times they show an effect of someone turning into a group of bats was pretty cool, but then they reuse that same effect over and over again. To make matters worse, using it so much obscured a lot of what was going on in and around it.

 This leads me to what is probably my biggest gripe: the bowdlerization of what is actually some fairly adult source material. Leaving aside the sexual metaphor of being bitten by a vampire for a little bit, Vlad in real life was an extremely violent and cruel man who intimidated invading armies by impaling people on stakes for them to see, hence his nickname. Not that the film needed to show this happening, but in general the film goes out of its way to obscure violence of any kind, be it sword fights or whatever. For a film about a bloodsucking madman, this film is curiously lacking in that department. What few battle sequences there are also take place at night, and the darkness serves as yet another way of hiding the brutal reality of medieval warfare. The film also neuters its source material by eliminating almost any sexual connotation associated with being bitten by a vampire, and worst of all never shows any penetration when someone is bitten. All of this combines to create the feeling that the PG-13 was used for profitability instead of being a purely artistic choice.

 Still, I wasn't ever bored while watching this. Sure, the story wasn't too original or even that well written, but despite my complaints I still think that this will satisfy the demographic its being targeted towards. The acting is decent, as is the general look of the film, despite being overly dark in some scenes. Overall, it probably won't win over any fans of previous versions of Dracula, but it is a suitably entertaining popcorn movie for the tween/teenage crowd.

This was a nice little popcorn movie.  The main reason to watch this is the performance of Luke Evans. I first noticed him when he completely stole the show in that otherwise mediocre Edgar Allan Poe movie with John Cusack (the Raven).  The guy has a sincere, brooding quality on screen, and he was well-cast though maybe ineffectively used in The Hobbit. I've been thinking that this guy is a budding superstar, and it was interesting to see him in a project like this since playing Dracula seemed to fall outside the heroic type character he seems destined to play.  Was this going to be a career defining role?  Would it show off a range we didn't know he had?

Well...what they did was rewrite the whole Dracula mythos to make him kind of heroic. Honestly, I didn't have a problem with that because we've seen Dracula come to life so many times that it's nice to see a new twist on the old story.  Luke Evans does make Dracula appealing, he even makes him seem noble.  He does this all while also making Dracula appear very, very deadly.

Put it this way, even before Evans becomes a vampire, he's the guy who goes marching into battle without a sword. It's as if he's thinking, "meh...why bother...I'll just grab one from one of my enemies and then keep it after I've cut the guy to ribbons."  The more nonchalantly you're able to pull off this little maneuver, the cooler you look (and Evans is as nonchalant as they come).

So, yes, Evans is memorable from this film, but that's just about the only thing. That being said, there are rumors that this film turned enough of a profit that we might be treated to a sequel or two. When the next one comes out, I'll grab it and be assured of another good popcorn night. Fans of action will be entertained, fans of horror (and Dracula specifically) will probably be disappointed by this one.  This is an enjoyable work easy to revisit.

I'm not sure why critics were so harsh in their reviews of this movie. I admit that I didn't see it in theaters because it was so widely panned. Most of the reviews objected to the plot, to the humanization of Vlad, and to the "video game/superhero" action sequences but in this movie these are to me it's strongest features. Also, all of these things have appeared, in lesser or greater effect, in the dozens of retelling of Dracula.  In this movie, the tropes worked. Love is stronger than death, Monsters are MADE not born, and we live or die by the choices we make. Dracula (1992) had a similar premise, albeit with more ambiguity, and okay, greater cinematic flair. Make no mistake, it is NOT an Oscar contender but it worked for me. It was thrilling, the actors gave excellent performances and it was not a stupid movie. And the action scenes were dope. ALL the stars. Please let there be a sequel.

Great story-line and special effects with the opportunity to be 'sequeled' into later historical times after this takes us through Dracula's beginning.  Always satisfying to see the Persian empire lose more great battles when they very much deserve it for compelling our hero to choose between his family and his humanity.  Given the whole 'burning-up' in sunlight dilemma, just not sure all the nighttime and overcast day battles make the odds much more likely against the Persian's sheer numbers.  Definitely worth seeing for any family like ours, who have an unquenchable thirst (pun intended) for more entertaining vampire stories!

I had many doubt the legitimacy of another vampire movie when I recommended this one, but I have had none walk away disappointed. The story of Vlad the impaler is one that many do not know Dracula was derived from. He was notorious for impaling the soldiers in his enemies' armies and was even noted for having once forced a defeated enemy to eat his family after seeing them cooked alive. With Vlad's history set aside, this story is extremely well told and incorporates the idea a vampires into this history lesson without causing too much disbelief. The animation is superb and the acting done by Charles Dance and Luke Evans convinced me of the plausibility of a man so desperate that he would "sell his soul to the devil". I have seen some negative reviews, but it seems to be by those hoping this movie would be something different. This isn't Underworld and it certainly isn't a historically accurate piece of film, but taking this well crafted story for what is it, Dracula Untold delivers. It is fun to watch on a date or with the family and brings up some interesting concepts surrounding the legends of Vladmimir, the impaler.

I had lots of fun with this movie. As many have said before, this is a half based on history and half Universal's attempt at making Dracula an action hero. I don't have a problem with this (of all the old monsters in Universals library Dracula seems the most poised at this attempt). Mr Luke Evans does a great job at portraying the protagonist, when the camera is on him, he is all you see.

The CGI work is good and it serves it's purpose. I suppose if one wanted to poke holes in the story or certain aspects about the movie one could, like how a freshly minted Dracula has almost complete mastery over his new found skills almost immediately, yet struggles with certain pedestrian tasks.

But these are movies after all, and action movies at that. Some suspension of disbelief is required and the greatest question one must ask is, "are you having fun?" and "are you being entertained?"

The movie delivers. You may quench your curiosity. It may not have done exceptionally well in the theater but that fact alone should not make you stay away.

In May od 1897 the manager of the Lyceum Theatre in London published a supernatural novel to supplement his income.  That novel was Dracula.  That manager of the famous theatre was a man named Bram Stoker.  In his fictitious novel the main character is a 400-something-year old nobleman from Transylvania who happens to crave human blood and is pretty much immortal, along with other amazing powers.  He is one of the most famous fictional characters of all time.  He was also loosely based of a man who actually existed.  Vlad III, Prince of Wallachia.  Vlad The Impaler.  From the House of Draculea, a branch of the House of  Basarab.  Vlad Dracula.  Well, Dracula Untold is the more accurate story of Vlad III, minus some of the Stoker-isms, but not all.  Vlad III(Luke Evans) must pay tribute to the Sultan (Dominic Cooper) in order to keep the peace in Transylvania (Romania), but when the Sultan demands 10,000 young boys to join his army, Vlad is perplexed.  When he visits the Sultan to reason with him, the Sultan takes everything a step further and demands that among the 10,000, Vlad's son should be counted.  Torn between protecting his family and starting another war with the Turks, Vlad defies the Sultan by killing his envoy.  With war eminent and their slaughter on the way in the form of the Turkish army, Vlad seeks out the aid of a nether-worldly creature skulking in a cave amongst the Carpathian mountains.  A vampire (grotesquely portrayed by Charles Dance).  Dracula Untold is fast-paced and dark, yielding a closer historical  version of Vlad Tepes  than Stoker originally proffered to us.  Action packed and brutal with loving touches hidden here and there.  My only issue is the PG-13 tag.  I would have like to see what the adults didn't get to see.  And the little story swish of Vlad The Impaler.  In the film the Sultan implies that Vlad's reputation as the impaler was under his life as a political prisoner, in the Sultan's army.  We know that isn't the case.  The actual Vlad was reputed to do terrible things with his victims, impaling and such, to build a frightening reputation in order to keep his country safe.  Word of his horrors spread far and wide, keeping enemies thinking twice about roaming into his lands.  In Romania Vlad is considered a hero.  He was considered a remarkable man.  A fresh take on an old story.  Definitely worth the watch.

First off, I was hesitant on whether or not Dracula Untold would be any good considering that it's only rated PG-13, but it turns out that I was happily surprised at how much I liked it.  I'm the type of person who love superhero origin stories, and that's exactly what Dracula Untold ended up being.  That being said, this film is not your typical vampire movie, and instead of focusing on the horror aspects of vampires Untold puts a superhero like twist on the classic legend of Dracula.  Furthermore, Untold showed audiences a side of Vlad that films in the past had never shown, and felt like a refreshing take on a role that's been played to death.  No pun intended.  Film fans finally saw the human side of Vlad before he becomes the monster known as Dracula, but that's not where the good ends in Untold.  I loved the locations the film makers chose, even though some locations were not historically accurate, but they did fit the mood of the film perfectly.  Lastly, I want to point out how good the acting was, especially the acting of Charles Dance (Game Of Thrones) who played the role of The Master Vampire.  The bottom line is that Dracula Untold is not your typical vampire movie, and is more like a super hero action origin story than a film that focuses on the scary side of vampires.  I highly recommend seeing this film at least once, especially if you like Game of Thrones.  I really hope there's going to be a sequel, because they left many questions unanswered, but some times it's a good thing to have questions after a film.

"Dracula Untold" does a great job developing the character of Vlad (Dracula) from the legend. It is an interesting and exciting retelling -- adding more depth with the addition of his wife and son. His character is more sympathetic. His ability to be a monster or a hero - as the situation calls for -- is what makes the movie interesting. Special effects and displays of his immense power are what make the movie exciting. It is fairly well plotted (a good thing, because I believe movie goers are sick to death of bad plots these days). Many films in this genre spend too much time concentrating on developing the character and not enough time showing what the hero can do once special powers are acquired. The hero's abilities are what sets him apart from the rest of us, and part of what makes him fascinating. In "Dracula Untold," the viewer gets to witness some fabulous shows of power, but also of character - both the good and bad. Good movie for this genre. I do recommend it.

I watched this movie without great expectations.  For me, that's a good thing because when I anticipate being a little disappointed it helps prevent me from expecting too much.  ("Frozen" is an example.  From all the rave reviews, I expected it to be a knock-out movie.  I was sorely let down by it.)  I was underwhelmed by the trailers I had seen for "Dracula Untold" but there were enough positive customer reviews to prompt me to take a chance.  Obviously, this movie is fiction but it is one that I felt blended historical fact, fiction, and mythology quite nicely.  Other reviewers are much better than I at analyzing the movie so I will not tread that ground again, only render my own overall opinion.  Though flawed, "Dracula Untold" is a refreshing take on the vampire mythology, one that mercifully does not include sparkly vampires.  Vlad is a flawed yet noble antihero, one who is willing to sacrifice himself for the good of his people and his family; a man willing to reluctantly embrace darkness in order to protect his loved ones and those under his leadership.  I found Luke Evans' portrayal to be surprisingly relatable; taking us from the man to the myth with a deft mixture of tenderness, fierce protectiveness, and a touch of quiet humor.  There were some things that disappointed me, like the perpetuation of the erroneous belief that sunlight can destroy Dracula (Is Hollywood really that adverse to reading the actual source material??) and trying to convince me that a human can plummet an ungodly distance and still be conscious, unbloodied, intact, and able to speak coherently...  (Yeah, I'm still gnashing my teeth about that because they could have worked around the issue.  I get Sheldon Cooper about such details when they so flagrantly fly in the face of logic, physics, and/or biology.  I can suspend disbelieve only so far.  But I digress.)  While "Dracula Untold" is not a great movie, I feel it is an interesting and fun take on a well-worn, nearly threadbare, subject.  "Bram Stoker's Dracula" is still my favorite vampire movie though, despite Winona Rider's flinch-after-death and Keanu Reeve's usual wooden acting.  With the exception of the ever-fascinating Gary Oldman's magnetic performance in "Bram", I think the acting in "Dracula Untold" is more even.  I think it was an excellent choice to select actors for their talent rather than how big a box-office draw their name brings.  Luke Evans was a pleasant surprise and Charles Dance gave his usual solid performance, giving his character a slippery yet somehow almost regal quality.  I look forward to watching it again.

Dracula Untold has more actual historic facts than most films of this type. The Ottoman Empire is Dracula's nemesis just like Vlad the Impaler's was in real life. I found this origin story of Dracula to be interesting, most movies involving Dracula never include his origin. All though most of the actors speak with a British accent, you soon stop noticing. Vlad must do whatever is necessary to protect his family and fellow Transylvanians from the monster that is the Ottomans. Now he must deal with the consequences of his decisions. I hope there is a sequel!

When they referred to him as Vlad III I thought someone finally got their history correct. But alas, no. Vlad III was Vlad Dracul, the ruler whom Bram Stoker based his novel. Vlad IV was his son Vlad the Impaler. A couple of amateur historians in the 70s made the same mistake many before them had and confussed the father with the son, and the mob bellieved them.  There never was a Vlad Dracula (except briefly Vlad IV's son who died in infancy without issue).

I'm sure that there will be people who review this and will be kind of harsh. I thought that it was a different take on the legend of Dracula, here we have him as a loving father and husband and ruler who is trying to give his family and subjects and good life free of Turkish intervention. What he does he does so that his people can live. Luke Evans is Dracula and he has the part down pat in as far as this story is put forward. Dominic Cooper is his ex-friend and ruler of Turkey who tries to force Dracula to give him the children of Transylvania to add to his army. The performances of those two and some others are terrific. The wife and kid, well a little annoying and not the best actors but....overall I just enjoyed it.

I have a few complaints about this movie.
1. Dracula's son depreciated the value of this film.  He seems like a little crybaby or young girl.  For a multimillion dollar movie, the director should have selected a stronger, more dominant boy.

2.  Vlad used the wrong swords throughout the entire movie.  The real Vlad the Impaler used a wicked curved sword known as the Kilij.  Unlike the actor in this movie, the real Vlad was not a fool.  He understood that the Kilij can cause severe damage to human flesh with the fraction of the effort of using a standard long sword.

3.  The impalement scenes are not correct.  Only blunt poles were used by the true Vlad the Impaler to prolong agony.  Also, the insertion of these blunt tools were different.

4.  The vampire bats of this movie do not make any sense to me.  True vampire bats originate and dwell in Central American/South America. They prefer to lap up blood from chickens and cattle.  There is no way that any vampire bat evolved in Transylvania/Walachia.

6.  For someone who tries to be so masculine, the main actor is practically hairless all over like a teenage boy.  He should at least try to grow a beard if he thinks he can bark orders at seasoned veterans.  I was surprised that he did not have a genuine goatee at least.

My point is that the director did not do his research adequately.  Because of this ignorance. I give his movie a single star. I could have directed a significantly better film than the ignorant director.

Luke Evans is wasted in this movie. He is obviously a talented actor, that showed despite his starring in this horrible movie. That his acting ability shone through bad dialogue, boring scenes and impossible plot says alot for him. It is a real shame he didn't land in a better role. I will look for his next film.

Dracula Untold should have been good. It has everything, vampires, swords, fight scenes, great sets and costumes, but it was terrible. My sister fell asleep and I played on my phone the whole time. The dialogue is bad, out of character and doesn't fit either the setting, the subject or the characters. I got the distinct impression that this whole script was written by an adolescent boy. Every scene that was supposed to be scary, suspenseful and excite was instead utterly boring. Every fight scene was either skipped or shown in bits and pieces through reflections or shadows. I'm not sure if this was to cut down on blood and gore (if that's true, why even bother making a VAMPIRE movie at all) or to save money on special affects, but it was a huge epic fail. Again, why bother with a vampire movie at all if you're going to out right skip the blood?

The plot was just implausible to the point of being utterly ridiculous. Characters make a harrowing climb of a mountain cliff in minutes without a stain on their clothes and aren't the least out of breath, a monster in a save up this isolated, monstrous cliff has a cave full of skeletons of men he's killed because apparently travelers without family or friends just happen to stumble into that cave all the freaking time, and when our hero has 3 days to destroy his enemies, he spends entire nights brooding and worrying and basically wasting time. Bad guys show up in the throne room unannounced and everyone is shocked because I guess there are no guards or look outs or staff to announce their approach or presence? And, to top it all off, Turkey seems to be full of blond, blue eyed men and women.

Like I said, my sister fell asleep and I ended up reading terrible reviews about this movie online, something I definitely should have done BEFORE I paid money for this.

Then, we watched the Maze Runner, en excellent, exciting, well done film. After I wanted that movie, I went online and bought not only the movie but the entire trilogy. Don't believe all the 5 star reviews, Dracula Untold is terrible.

Highly recommended!

VERY much enjoyed Dracula Untold. I'm a huge fan of Dracula movies, but very picky because of all the campy things you find. This new version provides the backstory of Vlad the Impaler, and I found the ending unexpected and very romantic. The writers used the issues with ISIL to their advantage in the brutality of the Turks -- for example, the taking of thousands of small boys and forcing them into battle. I found myself seriously involved, rooting for Vlad's meager army as they fought against them. I loved the character of Vlad and this entire backstory. And I really loved the glimpse into the future offered in the final scene. It's fast moving -- and the backstory provides an entirely new slant. This is not an intellectual film by any means, but it gives the old mythologies fresh blood.

This movie surprised me with how much I actually liked it. I loved the fresh perspective of post-battlefield Vlad, and seeing such a completely different side of the story. By the end of the movie I find myself still wanting more, and the ending is just the perfect little intriguing and touching encounter. An absolutely superb movie. An intriguing and suspenseful supernatural tale masterfully weaved with accurate historical facts. Great actors, great costumes, great drama, great special effects, great music, and not least excellent production, editing, and directing. The ending is perfect. Ignore the naysayers and watch it. It's deliciously shocking. There was a reviewer who started by giving away the whole film (hello, spoiler), then in an effort to look like a wannabe film critic got stingy with the stars. I would give it 6 stars, because it embodies everything a movie experience should have: it's engaging, it draws you in, it shows you what happens to everyone it introduces, it settles the score between protagonist and antagonist, and you feel good walking out while the credits roll. So it's not only a good movie, it's a template for what any movie that wants to be good should be like.

This movie puts a slightly different twist on the Dracula we know and have come to love. I like the idea that he wasn't all bad, and he "made a deal with the devil" so to speak, to save his family and his people that looked to him for their very survival.  This is thought provoking in that, maybe he became a vampire as a sacrifice versus what we have always known that he became a vampire out of just sheer anger and revenge. In this movie he uses his dark powers more positively than we have read or seen in any other media source. Applause for the actor, the settings, and costuming, not to mention the graphics. And best of all, for the price, you get blu ray, dvd, and the ability to register this movie for streaming purposes, what a deal!!!!!!!

When this movie first came out I had serious doubts about it because of all the films about Dracula and most of them not very faithful to the
Book or the legends of Vampires.  The only movie that portrays the original story more or less correctly was BRAM STOKERS DRACULA.  This
movie while entertaining and worth seeing if you don't care about the accuracy of the story then you might want to get it, its not expensive.  The
effects are good, acting fine and some good haunting Transy settings.  But I found the story, well, pretty awful.  They could not even get the names
correct: Dracula means Son of the Dragon; this Dracula says it means Son of the Devil....NOT CORRECT!  Vlad Dracula did terrorize the Moslem
Turks but with stakes through the butts, not by sucking their blood or beating them to death with bat poo.  He became known as Vlad the Impaler
not Vlad the  Hicky giver!  And to my knowledge Vlad the younger did not have any sons, though I  could be wrong about that.  His wife did jump
off a tower and killed herself when she thought Drac was dead.  She was not pushed off a Turk.  The sun does not kill Vamps though this movie
continues the silly idea: Vampires usually sleep in a box or coffin contain their native soil; that helps them regenerate their powers.  It they go
out  in the daytime the sun weakens their powers and makes them easier to kill.  Best head for the ole coffin for a nice days rest & recovery.
Who was that creature in the cave at the beginning; was that supposed to be the Devil?  Ughy chap and Nassstttyyyy.
  Still, I give it a passing grade for entertaining values and good production techniques.  And I like LEGENDARY PICTURES  who probably
the primary producers of this interesting if confusing story telling and a good cast.  THREE STARS but I do recommend this for Dracula and
vampire admirers but not for those who like to see classics such as DRACULA (the book) more accurately portrayed .  I got mine from Amazon,
enjoy and keep a crucifix handy!

Here's what I'll say. In the action movie canon, there are formulas. We know them, we kind of love them, but we can grow tired of them. I was, admittedly, expecting as much from this film. Yes, it was sold as a darker take on the Dracula myth, but I figured "Sure it is. There's no way Luke Evans isn't the typical brooding but heroic protagonist who gets the movie star moments and lines." And that's where this story surprised me. It's dark. Like not the cinematography, though admittedly that's the case. Evans is a broken man in this story, and while you're rooting for him in theory, you don't ever think "Yeah, I totally trust him, I know he'll do the right thing."

The visuals are 75% echoes of things we've seen before, but the 25% that's new is very new and different. Again, that's kind of why I'm giving it the rating I'm giving. This wasn't a summer big, 4th of July film. It kind of snuck up on me, and I was just...happy with it. Satisfied that I'd seen a good story, by people who wanted to do something genuinely different ... which is not all that common.

Part of the story is based on an obscure ancient legend that there used to be a school in the Fagaras Mountains of Romania, near Sibiu, where students learned witchcraft.  The school was called Scholomance and the graduates were called Solomonari, which is related to the character of Solomon in the Tanakh (Old Testament).  The teacher in the mountains was rumored to be Satan.  All in all a great film!  Romance, drama, action, story, characters.  I only wish it had been 60 minutes longer so we could have had the backstory more complete of Vlad's childhood, father, and Vlad's exploits as "Lord Impaler."  This would have made it the most complete and unbeatable version of the story, even than the Francis Ford Coppola version from 1992, which still stands out as the most incredible version ever!

Despite being fantasy the movie catches the historical truth better than most factual movies.  The Ottoman Turks were terrifying and Vlad Dracula fought them, despite their huge military apparatus.  The Ottoman Empire did take Janissaries from their conquered peoples. The Ottomans were the continuation of the Roman Empire, complete with slavery. Western Europe owes its life to this man and others who fought the Ottomans and this movie captures the immense sacrifice and their historical continuing presence as an allegory.

...and sometimes it needs a good ol' monster movie. And if you're looking for a lavish, action-packed, solid origin tale for Count Drrrraculaaa, look no further than Dracula Untold. This movie genuinely impressed me. I went in expecting a movie filled with generic action, bad dialogue, a turgid romance and over-acting. What I got was one-and-a-half hours of royal entertainment, sumptuous costumes, lavish sets, dazzling special effects and an excellent performance from Luke Evans! I left feeling satisfied and excited.

But yeah, this movie has all those flaws too. Dracula Untold has a simple storyline and is littered with fantasy cliches (Gary Shore is no Peter Jackson). It's early action scenes are muddled, filmed with shaky cam and butchered in the editing room. The dialogue is overblown and a few of the actors are a little questionable. Oh, and PS, this movie gets no points for historical accuracy. There, that's all the flaws out of the way. Now we can focus on the awesome parts in this movie, and there are MANY of those.

First off, the best word I can use to describe this movie is sumptuous. This is a sumptuous movie. Legendary costume designer Ngila "Lord of the Rings" Dickson deserves an Academy Award for designing the most lavish and downright beautiful costumes, armor, and robes this side of Middle Earth. When coupled with the equally lavish, rich, and stunning sets, you have the look of a downright gorgeous movie any way you cut it.

I guess the visual style needs more mentioning. The movie starts off muddled, unsure of whether it should go full blown Gothic or for a more sleek and modern polish. The action scenes are missing that bite (no pun intended) that will come in later. But as we advance, director Gary Shore gets more comfortable with the shadows, rainy forests, and open flames, and starts filming shots that are grandiose and epic in the best way. A field of a thousand corpses, a red cape blowing on a cliff, a man walking in a lightning storm...these are the shots that make cinema worthwhile! Oh, and the special effects are actually rather dazzling. They give the action scenes that extra oomph and are also just spectacular to watch.

Speaking of spectacular, this is Luke Evans's movie all the way. Bringing that same calm gravitas, moral certitude, and quiet power that he brought to Bard the Bowman, Luke Evans holds the screen and the attention with his portrayal of the flawed yet noble Prince Vlad. It's a performance that's far better than it needed to be, and the movie is better for it too. Charles Dance gets to chew scenery (and people) as an ancient and powerful vampire, and Dominic Cooper is also having fun as the Sultan Mehmed, an all-powerful bully with impeccable hair. In all the cast is solid, while the mighty Luke Evans is the true standout.

In conclusion, while muddled, occasionally cliched, and perhaps lacking a bit of gravitas, Dracula Untold is absolutely a movie I recommend to fans of fantasy, epic war films, or good ol' fashioned vampire fun. It's led by the excellent Luke Evans, features some dazzling special effects, epic action, and some real human (sorry, vampire) drama about what it means to be a monster. 4/5 blood-sucking stars! Now where's my sequel?

Loved it, really solid Dracula film that lays the ground for a whole new slew of Universal Monster movies.  The plot was a bit rushed at some points, but Luke Evans really slips into the role.  Charles Dance is also wonderful in another amoral role, hopefully to show up in more of the new monster movies.
Sequel please! Great Sci fi, The good guy within the bad, very popular concept these days. i hope to see a sequel soon!

It was really nice to see a good Dracula film made again. It has been too long since we've had a decent Vlad "The Impaler" story on the screens. I enjoyed watching this movie for its lack of drag, amazing shots and its own twists on the events.

I love a good action movie and this one was great! LOVED IT!  Of course, it is also a love story...it is Dracula, you know. Such a terrific story line. The characters were all terrific and well played by their actors. I couldn't have been happier. I don't have any complaints. Fantastic date night movie with the one you love. :)

I saw Dracula Untold in the theatre, and was I impressed! It was everything I was hoping for And more!!! I am so excited to now own it!!! The story line is awesome!! The cast was phenomenal!! And the possibility of a sequel OMG!!!

Solid mixing of historical fact, folklore, and fiction.  And a damn good action-horror film.  Vlad is likable, admirable, brave, and forced into a lose-lose situation.  Compelling him to strive against two scary foes, all to save his beloved family (and his ungrateful people).  Incredible performances throughout, beautiful settings, and excellent special effects.  We also get treated to a surprise ending that promises a sequel.

Dracula Untold has its flaws, though.  Some really annoying ones, so be warned (LIGHT SPOILERS AHEAD):

The violence is excellent, except when it gets mired in special effects.  The writers got way too bat-happy with this story.  Almost to the point of ruining some spectacular scenes.  Ok, we get it.  He can control bats and fly in the form of a colony of bats.  When Vlad fights in the form of a man, the fun is back on.  When the bats arrive, it just feels like lazy production and storytelling.

Characterization of Vlad and his wife and child are sufficient, but nobody else--nobody--gets any characterization.  So, when certain plot twists go down, we are left wondering why.  Sometimes asking, "So what?"  Interesting-looking minor characters on both sides remain cardboard set pieces.  Not cool.  This movie could have been a more in-depth epic.

Then there are the unexplained stupidities:

Vlad is instructed that he can also use any other creatures considered of the night.  See through them, sense through them, use them in battle.  Where were they?

He has powers of telekinesis like his creator.  Why didn't he use them?

Why do his vampire children turn on him?  He can't control them?

Why do they instantly view humanity as the enemy?  Vlad didn't when he was turned.

Then we have the Sultan.  He is SOOO comfortable with having to face Dracula and potentially Dracula's sire!  Why?  We are given no reason to understand this wacko confidence he has in himself.  How did he know to use silver in his battle?  Frankly, it ruined the tension.  Again, lazy writing.

Why does silver weaken and harm vampires?

Does sun kill vampires or not?  Vlad takes quite a few hits from the sun.  One a very nasty, unexpected attack.

The son of Dracula narrates in the beginning.  Then, we have no idea what became of him in the end.  He runs off with an oddly-knowledgeable priest, yes.  (Never a good idea for a young boy.)  But why is he narrating if he has nothing special to do with the story?  And why is that weird priest acquainted with vampires?  Nothing explained.  Lazy writing.

Lazy writing almost kills this retelling of Dracula.  But there are enough tense moments, horrific encounters, and displays of vampirism in this film to keep you watching till the end.  The actors are PERFECT.  I cannot stress this enough.  They really kept the movie rolling when the logic failed.  Luke Evans is a spectacular Vlad Dracula.  Sarah Gadon and Art Parkinson as well.  Truly believable love story and father-son relationship brought to LIFE by these two!

I'd LOVE a sequel with the same actors, but none of the writers.

4 STARS FOR THE ACTING AND EFFECTS.  -1 STARS for lazy writers.

awesome  bad ass  love it

I'm normally very, very critical of movies - technical errors in plot, or effects, poor acting, over-abuse of CGI, etc...

This movie, though suffers from some slight errors; overall it is enjoyable and, one of the few movies I haven't skipped through in recent years. A far superior movie to the entire Hobbit franchise; that's for sure - and enjoyable as its own take on the Dracula mythos. Also, Charles Dance does indeed, fill the roll of "elder?" vampire quite nicely; and Luke Evans is a very good face, and actor, for this role. But, that's just my opinion as a casual movie-goer with an over-abundance of the inability to suspend disbelief.  5 out of 5 stars from me, good enough.

I was pleasantly surprised since Dracula Untold got such horrific reviews when it was in theatres. It's too bad...since now it won't get the deserved sequel in which Universal had planned to bring together the classic monsters, including Frankenstein's monster and the Wolfman. Be that as it may,  this is a great origin story for the classic Count. A little over the top but still loads of fun.

I adore Luke Evans and his portrayal of Vlad Tepes and his transformation into Dracula is a wonderful on. Not just because he is able to capture the ferocity and might of Dracula's legend, but also because he is able to show the audience that Vlad Tepes and Dracula have more than one dimension. Dominic Cooper was also fantastic in this movie, it would have been nice to see more of him as he was the primary nemesis, but the film does justice to the Dracula legend. It is not overbearing in gore, but creative with displaying the destructive and protective force that Vlad Tepes is thought to have been, while also standing up to the legend of Dracula, in a manner that is not too Hollywood. This story, while told many many times, in this case, was offered up in a different light, giving the viewer a chance to take in the characters in a manner which has not yet been seen in cinematic tradition of the retelling of Bram Stoker's Dracula. Additionally. the filmmakers do well to create a final scene that would allow them to return and pick up for a sequel that would not seem too forced. All in all, great film, wonderful performances, the graphic affects were great, especially with the bats and the way Evans' eyes shone red. I would definitely recommend this be seen by any Luke Evan's lover, appreciators of the Dracula story, and for general entertainment as it would also be a good film to pop in and watch with friends and/or family on a Friday or Saturday night.

Possible Spoilers

This is a film whose premise is to create a beginning; a back-story if you will, for the narrative of Count Dracula. Thus, this re-imagined story of Vlad the Impaler, as the man who makes a deal with a proto-vampire - to save his people from the threat from the Ottoman Empire. Universal Picture's intends the film, to be a vehicle for its foray into the first of a series of re-imaged Universal Monster Films.

Visually, the film has the necessary iconography to encompass the Dracula character, while also managing to `ground' that iconography in its Medieval-style setting that feels fresh when married to, what could be considered over-exhausted foundation material. This is a film with good pacing, but the film's middle section feels at times mixed up and disjointed; it's hard to see certain scenes as sequential, a film that is more action drama - than horror.

Dracula Untold is not a deep film - it is a re-introduction, which is rather a good basic genre fare; it is comparatively fun in its portrayal of the monster in another light. While this film may not be very engaging as a standalone story, it does feel like a suitable entry point. With actors such as Evans and Dance in the mix - and add into the synthesis an alternate history there is still potential there.

Though critically panned, Dracula Untold is not that bad, as far as its visuals and the performance of the star Luke Evans as Vlad is concerned. Also, accusing the film of its historical inaccuracies is pointless because this is a dark fantasy about one of the most famous iconic characters in Western culture, not about the real Vlad, who is thought to be the model of Bram Stokers Dracula.

In the new film Vlad appears as a wise and respected ruler with a dark past, who has to make a tough decision when the Turkish Sultan Mehmed II (Dominic Cooper) demands an impossible tribute including one involving Vlads own son Ingeras (Art Parkinson). But what can a small country like Transylvania can do, except accepting an offer from Master Vampire (Charles Dance) living in the deep cave? (Actually, the real Vlad was the ruler of Wallachia, but thats not the point.)

What is disappointing about the film is the lack of suspense. The films story attempts to interest with a few choices Vlad has to make, but most of us know the result from the beginning. Despite the impressive CGI, action sequences lack style and the character development is not very interesting.

Bam! Dracula untold is one of the reboots of the universal monster line. Following I frankenstien, dracula untold take a little from all visions of this epic character. This movie was non stop action and built up for the ending battle! The cgi is so great it made my scrotum schrivel like a 14 year olds first time! If you like good movie this is the one!!

I honestly do not know if it was because i went into this movie knowing precisely what i was going to see and therefore there was no chance at my expectations being not met, if it was because it shows that sometimes the last thing that a person should do is listen to critics, or i was just in the mood to see this, but i absolutely LOVED this movie!

first of all, the acting was amazing!  Luke Evans was incredible in the role of dracula, i really felt for his character and with this performance, i am surprised that he is not a leading actor in hollywood right now.  all the actors on the whole were exceptional, yet he stood out the most.
the direction and visuals were wonderful and i enjoyed dracula's transformations while he flew through the armies, and i felt as if i was watching a greek tragedy: you already know the ending, but you are watching to see how matters unfold.
Sometimes, i have learned that the worst things to do is listen to other people when it comes to their preferences, because while some things are bad, there are those exceptions where something is good, but others look for the bad in it, so they find it.  If you go into this movie knowing what you are getting, you will see that it is quite wonderful and very well done.  is it perfect?  perhaps not, but what ever is?  also it was not deceptive.  if you watched the trailer for it, then it depicts the movie perfectly, instead of making it look better than what it was, or worse. overall, i would just say that sometimes don't knock things until you try them for yourself.  you may be surprised.

The idea of Dracula was inspired by a real, bloodthirsty man with a unique nickname, Vlad the Impaler.  This movie fuses the real life Vlad with the supernatural vampire version.  Vlad is faced with unsurmountable odds, the Turks are going to invade his land if he doesn't give them all male children to be used in war.  He knows that he can't defeat the Turks militarily and all attempts at diplomacy fail, so he ventures into the cave of a dangerous vampire.

It's about damn time somebody made a vampire movie with the "Vlad the Impaler" angle and its nice to step away from the recent adaptations of Vampires, such as Twilight; in which all of the Vampires look like Justin Beiber and seem ready to sprinkle pixie dust.

The movie has great action.  I like the idea of a vampire trying to take on an army with his powers.  The acting was pretty good and the characters are well developed.  A very entertaining and fun movie, highly recommended!

I enjoy watching this movie very much I went to see it three times! It did run a little shorter than I know a lot of people would have liked... But I think they set a good foundation if they wanted to make more movies :-)

In nearly every frame of its 92 minute run time, "Dracula Untold" answers the age old question: "What can they possibly do that is original with such a time worn character as Bram Stoker's vampire?"

  It is in the gothic atmosphere, lush and gloomy cinematography, dialogue and performances which recall perfectly Hammer's incantations of Dracula from the 60's and 70's with the lead performer, Luke Evans, giving resolve to the eloquent and classy feel of Peter Cushing and Christopher Lee's various turns as this character.

  Throughout the pacing is rapid-fire yet, it still finds time to find, pardon the pun, the pulse of these types of characters (namely fully fleshing the leads out as people the audience cares about) which very few Horror films in general get right anymore.

  The decidedly more "Lord of the Rings" than the classic Universal Monsters feel usually is incredibly off putting in these modern rebirths of age tested creatures (as it was in the travesty "I, Frankenstein") but here it works wonderfully. Those fearing the C.G.I. will be too heavy handed (as it often is) need not fear as the effects are mostly well done and convincing.

  Often the jokes fall flat but they are few and far in between. The landscapes and sets are beautifully designed and it never goes too over the top.

  I went into this doubtful and came out quite satisfied. It is a B movie, and it never really forgets it, but its an entertaining, fun and fairly old-fashioned one (which ends in a semi-unique and satisfactory way) that isn't completely true to the original novel but it doesn't completely disrespect its legacy either.

Luke Evans perfectly conveyed suffering, tenderness and, yes, a monstrous dark side. I love vampire movies. I was born and raised in Europe alongside the Romanian borders where I could see those mountains from the border on top of the hillside. I grew up with stories of Vlad Dracul and his battles. One should learn the European History to appreciate this movie. Way back in time, Turks ruled European countries. They took them one by one including my country. My great grandmother was a Hungarian that took refuge in Romania where she grew up. I believe all the stories she had told me about Vlad Dracul and the battles he fought against the Turks. Mr. Evans was excellent in this movie and was the movie its self because of some truth in the storyline. I loved it and cant wait for the DVD to be released so that I can add it to my other Dracula/Vampire movie collection. Humble opinion of a true Vampire aficionado. I was born in 1968; I grew up watching all the Bella Lagosi, Peter Cushing, Christopher Lee, Boris Karloff; etc. Vampire flicks. I have an extensive movie collection 1500+ movie collection which (I Will gladly share for free). Don't listen to the critics or "movie snobs."  This is a solid Dracula / Vampire film.  It has a different twist than any other Dracula film but that's what makes it so endearing. The cinematography is outstanding as well as the sets, costumes, and effects.  It touches on the history of Vlad Tepes but it's not historically accurate.  I found that a little dissappointing but it takes off and doesn't let up. It presents Dracula in a different type of light and character that really draws you in. I recommend this highly as one of the best Dracula films ever made.

I have to admit, I didn't think I would watch Dracula Untold and end up liking it. The previews were boring as hell. Luke Evans didn't seem like he had the talent to hold this project together. The MPAA slapped this with a PG-13 rating... Or was it director Gary Shore trying to reach a wider audience during the film's theatrical run? Either way, critics have universally panned Dracula Untold, and it holds (as of this date) a 24% aggregate rating on Rotten Tomatoes.

The story itself is different from other vampire films. You could call it a "prequel" of sorts. Luke Evans stars as Prince Vlad Tepes, the medieval Romanian ruler famous for impaling opposing armies during warfare, or according to popular history, often just for fun. Nobody was spared during these altercations, and it was common to see woman and children amongst infantry dying slow and agonizing deaths. In Dracula Untold, we see Vlad's good side, a unifying nationalist who is completely for his people. Vlad's gruesome hobby of impalement is only given a slight wink. The infection with the vampire curse occurs as a last resort to stave off an invading Turkish army. Vlad happens to discover an ancient vampire deep within a cave system earlier in the film, and seeks his affliction later on to help him him in battle and keep his people from being slaughtered. However, this altruistic gesture comes with a steep price: if Vlad drinks human blood within 3 days of being infected, he is permanently transformed into a vampire and his infecter is set free.

The best segment of Dracula Untold occurs when the Prince leaves all human company behind and thrusts himself into the Undead's den. Charles Dance is excellent as the ancient "Master Vampire," who is prehistoric in both age and appearance. The Master wears a cloak, with only his shriveled blue face and razor sharp nails visible. He is immediately stricken by Vlad's unwavering desire to be afflicted with the curse, and offers the Prince some of his blood. Vlad drinks this, gags, and finally collapses dead from this potent poison. He wakes up sometime later at dusk in the middle of a creek. It's at this point that director Gary Shore should have devoted much more screen time to allow Vlad the chance to test and become comfortable with his new found abilities. Vlad's vampirism is much like becoming a super-hero, and I feel the film would have been much better if it had placed more emphasis on the cultivation of his vampiric traits.

The film culminates with a large battle and one-on-one showdown with the Turkish Sultan. Aside from the acting talents of Luke Evans and Charles Dance, the rest of the cast is wooden, with some (such as the Prince's son) bordering on annoying. The story is more of a cliche medieval siege film than a vampire movie. The cloud of CGI bats that Price Vlad wields looks cheap, and is just plain bad film making. The final scene involves a random jump of about 500 years that is semi-interesting, but leads the viewer to believe that any sequels will evolve this franchise into an Underworld clone, or worse, Dracula 2000. Good vampire flick >>> 4 stars.

No. No, there won't be any asinine puns or jokes to be found here. It's already bad enough that vampires aren't regarded as the spawn of the Devil anymore in pop culture. Instead, they've been reduced to Dolce & Gabbana models that listen intently to emotionally incompetent teenage girls reading stupid poetry from their stupid binder in a stupid field of marigolds . It's stupid.

However, there have been a brave group of cinematic warriors who've fought the good fight to portray those who feast on the innocent in all of their unholy glory. Films like "Let the Right One In" and "Afflicted" have done justice to the mythological abominations.

"Dracula Untold", even though it tries its hardest to reach that level of potential, ends up being a wasted effort that would make Sysyphus himself depressed.

The first red flag makes itself known immediately thanks to the film's title. "Untold"? I guess all of those Hammer Dracula films, the Francis Ford Coppola remake, and a little thing called the "Internet" weren't sufficient enough to properly tell a concise background. Nevertheless, it does weave the vampire mythology with the history of the real life monster, Vlad the Impaler. Must be a boring job.

Like previous "adaptations" of iconic monsters like the Wolfman and Frankenstein, "Dracula Untold" tries to modernize the man and the mythos surrounding him by means of sub-par special effects. That's it. Beyond that, with the exceptions of Luke Evans' portrayal of Vlad and Charles Dances as the First Vampire residing in the cave, everything else consists of performers plucked from the local high school Actors Guild with equally cringe-inducing dialogue.

With that being said, both aforementioned actors try their best with what they're working with, and they succeed for the most part. Whereas Evans performance is above average, it lacks subtlety thanks to ham-fistedness and cliched screenwriting. Dances on the other hand, is the opposite. His presence onscreen, though outlandish and exaggerated, is not only intimidating and unsettling, but it has the calm, intellectual, and pitiful characteristics that should be, and was, the epitome of what modern vampires emanate(d) in widespread culture.

Its unfair to say that Dracula Untold didn't try hard enough, if at all. There was certainly effort and good intentions put forth, and while that is more than enough compared to recent alterations of the famed monster, it wouldve been a more worthwhile experience were it not for the rushed pacing and mediocre production values.

This is the best Dracula movie. I was disappoint in the reviews most people wrote on the different movie websites. This movie doesn't disappoint in the slightest. It goes from start to finish, it doesn't lag at all through the movie. I wanted to see the movie when I saw a preview for it. I hope that they will make a sequel to this movie. I highly recommend that anyone that likes Dracula needs to see this movie.

Look, it's like this. Vampire movies were cool once...with the first and third Underworld being the last of the acceptable vampire films that bordered what we don't like about vampire films today; sparkling vampires with a sweet breath that are over 100 hundred years old, but for some reason caught up in high school teen love triangles(what mature, wise 100 year old beings.) This movie brings back the "classic" in vampire films and if anything, is an anti-romance vampire flick...so, expect darkness and vengeance, but do not expect a film where the lovely, beautiful vampire lead gets the pretty lady. Instead, see it as a family man's life gone absolute wrong.

I went in with low expectations and was blown away. Fantastic storyline, amazing set, awesome special effects/CGI work, relatable characters and strong dialogue between them. I was extremely impressed with the directors, writers and producers: you can tell everyone on set really put in a lot of work to make this film as great as it could be. The ending DEFINITELY left us with a cliffhanger and I'm very much looking forward to a sequel in the next year or two.

This movie is brimming with plot holes, with mediocre character development and somewhat awkward pacing. However, it does get the feel of a decent Gothic Action archetype quite well

The story originates from Vlad the Impaler. The exposition tells about how he would impale thousands of turkish soldiers who invaded on his home of Romania. However, now they are back in greater numbers and he is desperate to stop them. On his journeys, he finds the cave where an ancient beast lives that he narrowly escapes, a "vampire". He heads back to this cave to make a deal with the vampire to gain the vampire's powers.

After that, it all follows a somewhat predictable plot line, but it feels like every seem has a big plot hole in it. There are times when you might find yourself scratching your head at something that just seems to _happen_ without rhyme or reason. A lot of times, things will happen that seemed contrary to the plot leading up to it. Pretty much, you just have to "accept" a lot of things and take them for what they are.
The characters are fairly mediocre. Vlad is the only character with any level of complexity, and was actually played quite well.

The movie tries to get that gothic action type movie feel, like Underworld or Van Helsing. It is pretty successful in this regard, but tends to lean more towards the action side than the gothic side.

In summary, a fun watch if you're just looking for something entertaining

The first time I saw the trailer I simply said ''nope". The second time I saw the trailer I said "no still not gonna see this one." It wasn't until one night watching a tv series I follow closely; the trailer for Dracula Untold showed once again, and after viewing it, I pondered that maybe Dracula Untold might actually turn out to be a decent movie. So finally, I decided oh what the heck, and today I got the opportunity to view the movie. And while I still had some doubt going in, my review of this movie will detail exactly why I feel the way I do about Dracula Untold.

Disputes have arisen between Vlad(our main character) and the Turkish armada. Not only are they a threat, but an order has been made that 1,000 boys must be offered to be trained for warfare. Consideration here quickly turns to desperation and soon Vlad comes across a mysterious man in a cave(who is not the nicest looking character in the world) who seems to have a solution to the problem: a sort of immortality. The price? Vlad must resist the urge for human blood in order to not become a full-fledged vampire.

Dracula Untold shines for many reasons. Luke Evans shows a lot of charisma and is definitely a stronghold throughout the movie. From his first appearance onscreen, all the way to his transition into the iconic character, he is a feat to watch. Sarah Gadon plays Mirena and does a good job; and I could definitely write a full review about how beautiful she is. Dominic Cooper portrays Mehmed in the movie, while he is not one of the movie's highlight performances I can call his performance satisfactory.

The effects/sound in the movie is also one of Dracula Untold strong suits', and the designs of the vampires are likable. Finally, the storyline this movie has is surely a good one. The suspense and the thrill of the first act, all the way to the cliffhanger ending of the final act keeps the movie viewer filled with intrigue, and in the end Dracula Untold is a movie I can definitely say GO SEE. And while I won't call Dracula Untold a 5 star movie I will rate it

4 Stars

Rated PG-13

Starring: Luke Evans, Dominic Cooper, Sarah Gadon, Noah Huntley, William Houston, Charlie Dance,

The ending has sequel written all over it with Charles Dance saying, "Let the games begin!"  Let's hope the sequel is as good as this one.

I loved this movie.  For some reason critics hate it.  It told the story of a man torn between love of his family and love and duty to his people and torn between terrible choices.  I eventually makes a terrible choice that could cost him everything but preserve his country and this tells a story of dracula filled with sacrifice and lose, but still retaining some of the classic horror element of being a vampire and just how badly it could all spin out of control. I went to the movie theater to unwind from a long work week, and to have a good, entertaining time with my friends, and this movie delivered on that, and to me that makes it a success.  It's not going to win any Oscars, but it's a really fun movie to watch.  There's some tongue in cheek humor, some good action scenes, and  Luke Evans did a decent job as the character of Dracula.  And as a bonus, you get a cameo by Charles Dance.

History is written by the victor - and in the classic stories, Dracula lost. The vampires lost, The vampire slayers and vampire enemies told the vampire story.

Here's how it might have been written by the son of the dragon himself. His kingdom, his family are beset by horrible enemies, outnumbered by thousands to one, with not an ally to be seen. The count's campaign to defend his people and family had its terrible moments, the ones convincing his foes to hold back for fear of, well, something. A battle averted is a battle won, isn't it, and those already dead after one fight won't be any more or less dead no matter how their remains are displayed.

But, no matter how terrible you want to be thought, someone more terrible will appear in reality. The prince's decision becomes to lose everything for himself alone, or to lose everything for his people and family. He chooses to become his kingdom's defender, as best he can, no matter the cost.

We've had some retellings of the classic vampire tale lately. The sparkly one (you know what I mean) launders the tale of sacrifice and loss, This dives headlong into it, and arises all the better for it.

-- wiredweird

Just saw this movie- Loved it! Was drawn into the human side of what seems like a purely evil character. Enjoyed Luke Evans portrayal of the prince. Hope to see him in many more movies... Thank You for great entertainment.

Dracula Untold, starring Luke Evans as Vlad Tepes, is entertaining for the first 2/3rd of the movie. Obviously when dealing with a lead character that is a vampire, we have to suspend belief when it comes to the actual historical facts regarding the real Tepes and the conflict between Wallachia and the Turks. Our fictional Vlad is a loving and sensitive father, husband, and beloved prince forced to resort to extreme measures to protect his people.  In this case, risking his eternal soul for three days of vampiric power in an effort to crush the Turkish army.

Im willing to forgive the artificial three day timeline only because it does echo some of the Eastern European folklore surrounding vampires (the notion that a person killed by a vampire would rise as one themselves in three days). In this case, the Master Vampire (played by Charles Dance) provides Vlad with an out clause. If he can actually last three days without drinking human blood, he will return to his human state.

The movie does a good job in the beginning of building the mythos in a way reminiscent of the classic Dracula vampire movies and establishing the scope of Vlads newfound vampiric powers and weaknesses. This is what you might call a traditional depiction of the vampire: able to transform into bats, night vision, enhanced strength and speed, preternatural senses, weather control, vulnerability to silver and sunlight, repelled by crosses. It was actually a pleasure to revisit this classic vampire motif in an era of vegetarian vampires that sparkle in the sunlight.

The film is also beautiful to watch. Some of the most disconcerting scenes were not the overt displays of bloodletting, but the disjointed view of battle reflected through the mirror finish of a sword blade.  During battle scenes, they made great use of slow-motion and awkward camera angles to create an air of relentlessness as Vlad tears through opponents.

But as the movie spirals toward the forgone conclusion, we get tripped up time and time again on contrived scenarios and Vlad apparently forgetting his own powers.

Warning: Spoilers ahead.

Vlads mastery over bats is established early in the movie. He can not only transform himself into bats, but he can command any bats within the range of his power (which, based on the final mass combat with the Turkish army, must be all of Eastern Europe.) We see him use his bat horde to knock people off cliffs, run down soldiers, and create a GIANT BAT FIST OF DOOM to smash into the Turkish army and scatter hundreds of soldiers at a time. And yet when his wife is on the verge of falling off the tower, instead of just directing the bats to save her he instead flies up there himself. Vlad, pal, the bats were RIGHT THERE! You just smashed a thousand Turkish soldiers, in full armor, with them. They can totally handle carrying your waif of a wife to safety.

This happens again in the big showdown fight with the Sultan, who has prepared for Vlad by standing on a pile of silver coins and wields a silver-plated sword. Lets forget for a moment that at no time in the movie did the Turks actually learn of Vlads weakness, and that there is nothing in Arabic folklore that would lead the Sultan to know Vlad should be vulnerable to silver. Vlad, buddy. The guy is standing in the middle of a pile of silver no more than twenty foot diameter. Use the bats to knock him out of it! You used this technique to knock down dozens of armored Turks on horseback. Did you suddenly forget you have this power?

Back to Vlads wife. Of course, she plummets to her death just as the sun begins to rise at the end of the third night. Vlad is about to lose his powers, because he totally nailed that blood thirst and is about to become human again. But their son is still in danger and she is dying anyway. So she offers her blood to him so he can condemn himself for eternity in order to save their son.

So now Vlad is a vampire permanently and has even more power at his disposal. He can summon up a thunderstorm so powerful it blots out the sun (allowing him to conveniently pursue the Turks that kidnapped his son. And you know, Im totally ready to buy into that. They had set up the mythos early so that we should expect an exponential power increase between a temporary vampire and a true vampire. But Vlad doesnt immediately go after his son. First, he goes back into the monastery and turns all the survivors into vampires.

First, there was no reason for this. He didn't need their help to fight the Turks at this point. He is completely OP at this point and can solo this. Second, he also knows that he is about to condemn to hell all of the people he had sworn to protect. This is completely out of character with the man we spent the first 2/3rd of this movie with. Third, if all he had to do was feed the dying a little blood to turn them into vampires, why didn't he turn his wife? He didn't need to drain her dry to become a vampire. The rules set forth in the beginning made that clear. He could have taken a drink and then returned the favor to revive her.

So now Vlad and his vampire army slaughter the Turks and he saves his son. And, predictably, the vampires turn on our hero and are going to eat his kid. Vlad parts the thunderstorm and lets the sun shine down, killing all of the vampires and himself.

And if it had ended with that, I probably would have forgiven the other issues. It would have been the proper tragic ending that should follow these sort of things. The road to Hell is paved with good intentions. Regardless of the nobility of his reasons, becoming a vampire shouldnt have a happy ending.

But apparently the filmmaker felt otherwise and decides to shoehorn a happy ending into the movie. We cut to the future and see Vlad walking down the street, when he comes across a woman who just happens to look exactly like his long-dead wife. And oh, how cute, when he recites his wifes favorite poem to this total stranger, she stops and proclaims that is her favorite poem! Love transcends all as the pair walk away together. That feeling of nausea I got wasn't caused by the popcorn.

Ultimately, Dracula Untold is a movie diminished by a script that depends too much on contrivances and a hero who apparently has a terminal case of selective amnesia.

What a great Origin story for Dracula!  My favorite Dracula tale before this one would probably be the less well known Dracula the Dark Prince that is sometimes shown on Syfy, which blends the historical and hints at the monster.  But it's too historical.  Dracula Untold for me had the perfect balance of Supernatural, Love story, Origin story, historical fact, and action.  All of these element came together so well to tell a story I never lost interest in.  I was expecting this to go the Underworld route and have that bit of scifi cornyness with no lasting power (which I would have put up with for Luke Evans sake), but it definitely did not.  Sophisticated Dracula for the next generation and the perfect starting point for Universal to relaunch it's Monsters line up. Go support it in theaters!

Loved the idea of looking back and glimpsing a version of what could have been pre-vampiric Dracula. I speculated that this movie, given the backstory premise, would not infringe upon or conflict with my long held Dracula favorites from a story perspective, and it absolutely did not. Dracula Untold managed to take what is already a fairly tragic figure and made the Dracula story even more tragic. So, this is a wonderful addition to the saga. Additionally, Luke Evans' portrayal was so amazingly warm and endearing that any of Vlad's brutality only added to the personal tragedy of the character. One bitter-sweet result from this movie - where I thought that I was safe in watching Dracula Untold as it would not conflict with old Dracula standards, I now find that I have a new favorite portrayal of Dracula on my hands; and, I cannot wait for what will surely be an incredible upcoming sequel(s).

Dracula Untold plays out similarly to Disney's Maleficent, where it isn't necessarily a remake or reboot, but a retelling, a 'what if this was actually how it happened'-style movie. The film follows Vlad the Impaler as he looks over Transylvania as Prince. But when the Turkish Sultan Mehmed II comes calling for a thousand boys from Vlad's kingdom, he decides the only thing he can do is confront the demonic force that lay within Broken Tooth mountain, where Vlad previously encountered the creature. Bestowed the unholy gifts of being a vampire, Vlad has three days to protect his kingdom, his family, and fend off the Sultan. But if he is to give into the thirst within those three days, he will remain this beast for eternity. Fighting the thirst, the Sultan's army and his own psyche, Vlad, a man of death who wanted to become a man of peace returns to his old ways in order to save those he cares for. But at what cost?

Dracula Untold is good filmmaking and story-telling, giving us a romantic tale mixed with themes of redemption, vengeance, courage, but most importantly, fear. Many people have criticized the depiction of Dracula, but again, this is a retelling. You can't think of Dracula the same way as you did in the Bela Lugosi '31 film or in Bram Stoker's Dracula in '92; this is a different monster, yet familiar. Luke Evans' performance, though, was without a doubt award-worthy and heart-wrenching; the man needs leading roles, because his talent cannot be contained. The supporting cast was good, but no one in particular stood out more-so than others. The visual effects, for the most part, were astounding but some scenes did need a little more work. The musical score from Ramin Djawadi was superbly dark and hauntingly epic, as if channeling his work on Game of Thrones into a more "Lord of the Rings" style score, with epic choral vocals and orchestral melodies. Gary Shore's direction was great, definitely in helping create the dark, grim and violent world of Dracula Untold. The script was good in that there was nothing cheesy about it, but there were many plot holes; the film should have been at least twenty minutes longer to add to the thin back-story.

Overall, Dracula Untold is a valiant and good effort, but falls short of being the vampire epic we deserve. But, the film is saved greatly, due in no small part to Luke Evans' acting, the visuals and the storytelling.

3.5/5 Stars

Keep in mind that this review is coming from a guy who likes: I Frankenstein, Van Helsing, and Super Natural.
This is a fun flick to just sit back and enjoy. Many online reviews have dogged on the movie rather harshly, don't look too much into it. As long as you have popcorn and a drink you'll probably enjoy the show. Granted many of the elements have been repeatedly shown in other movies, but they still gave us a fairly fun movie that attempts to tell the story of Dracula.

To start with, I was having a really bad day when I decided to watch this movie in theaters and It happened so quickly that the decision to watch it with a friend came out within 30 mins.
In short, The ticket was worth every penny I've paid.

I'm familiarized with Dracula movies and novels and I had thought that no movie might beat 1992 Bram Stoker's Dracula, but this one, with all of its dark elements did the job.

Maybe I liked it big time because it felt like a 92 minute rock music video (which I like).
The story line was smooth and fast, the acting was brilliant, the visual effects were excellent, the surprising and thrilling shots were the best and Luke Evans of course was wonderful with deep eye looks telling so much.

When friends who hadn't watched it asked my opinion, i answered "No regrets, go watch it as soon as possible"
Can't wait for a sequel (If there'd be any)

I've seen almost every movie about the titular character, including a few awful ones. This one delivers by providing some true facts about the real Vlad the Impaler. Features great music and a great performance by Evans, but CHARLES DANCE as the Master Vampire was awesome. There is a famous video game series called Castlevania. Someone in production must be a fan of the Castlevania games (especially the Lords of Shadows series) and the film benefits from those aspects. Fans of the game will know immediately what I mean.
It is completely different from other Dracula films, that is where its beauty lies. It would have been awesome to see Baba Yaga ( a witch who also appears in Castlevania), but those scenes were removed. The critics bashed it and it may not be doing great at the box office, but it is one of the best movies about the character that I've ever seen. You know there is something wrong in the world when you go to a movie theater, there's no line for Dracula Untold, but there is a LONG line ( and I mean LONG) of young girls who want to see ONE DIRECTION??? Let's hope for a sequel, for Dracula that is.

All I ask of movies like these is to make me believe...Luke Evans did just that! I too wish for a sequel. I am so glad that I ignored the critics. Sumptuous scenery & gorgeous soundtrack...I love all that were cast. Thank you Luke Evans for another Dracula to love...I have already pre-ordered this!

I enjoyed the movie immensely! The graphics (contrast between the light and dark, red and black) were stunning, music was crafted artfully with the scenes, and Luke Evans displayed an array of emotions, fierceness and artistic intensity with prowess! As far as I am concerned the movie did not disappoint; I walked away from the movie theater thoroughly entertained and looking forward to watching it again on DVD!

I would like to see a movie wherein, the hero never gets his/her butt kicked, but beats the daylight and crap out of evil combatants.  The story-line is predictable, dragged out in some scenes.  Another redundant ending like in other movies before it.
